Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:48D1-4540-01GN-61B6-00000-00Q1 2003 UnionBanCal Earnings Conference Call - Final2003-04-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:33ZLexisNexisTranscript 041703ae.720Q1 2003 UnionBanCal Earnings Conference Call - Final

OPERATOR: Ladies and Gentlemen, thank you for standing by. We do appreciate you patience in holding for our conference call this morning. We expect to be under way momentarily and ask that you please continue to hold.

Ladies and Gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to UnionBanCal first quarter 2003 earnings conference call.

At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. And later, we will conduct a question-and-answer session, with instructions to be given at that time. If anyone should require assistance during the conference, please depress zero, then star. As a reminder this conference is being recorded.

I would now like to turn the conference to our host, Manager of Investor Relations, Mr. Jack Rice. Please go ahead.

JACK RICE, UNIONBANCAL CORPORATION, MANAGER OF INVESTOR RELATIONS: Thank you. This is Jack Rice.

On the call with me are Richard Hartnack, Vice Chairman of the company; David Matson, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Philip Flynn, Executive Vice President and Chief Credit Officer. David Anderson, Senior Vice President and Controller, is here as well.

First, Mr. Matson will discuss the quarter's financial performance. Mr. Flynn will then review credit quality and other relevant loan portfolio details. Mr. Hartnack will conclude the call with an overall assessment of our performance, recent steps taken in execution of our strategic goals, comments about our operating environment, and other areas of investor interest. We will then open the call for questions and answers. We ask that each of you limit your questions to one lead and a maximum of a one follow-up question so that we may accommodate all questioners.

Before we begin, this conference call includes forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Forward-looking statements can be identified by looking at the fact that they do not relate strictly to historical or current facts. Often, they include the words: "believe," "expect," "anticipate," "intend," "plan," "estimate," "project," or words of similar meaning, or future or conditional verbs such as "will," "would," "should," "could," or "may." A number of important factors could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements.

These factors include fluctuations in interest rates, government policies and regulations, including monetary and fiscal policies, legislation, economic conditions, credit quality of borrowers, operational factors and competition in the geographic and business area in which the company conducts its operations, the war in Iraq and global political and general economic conditions.

A complete description of the company including related risk factors is discussed in the company's public filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. All forward-looking statements included in this conference call are based on information available at the time of the call and the company assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statement.

Thank you. Now Mr. Matson with the quarter's financial review.

DAVID MATSON, UNIONBANCAL CORPORATION, EVP AND CFO: Thank you Jack and thank you all for joining us this morning. The company earned 89 cents per share in the first quarter, 22 cents higher than the prior year.

Total revenue increased 6.7 percent and the provision for credit loss declined $25 million or 45 percent. Strengths in our deposit businesses continued to enhance net interest revenue and the deposit fee on a year over year basis. First quarter net interest income was up three percent compared to last year, despite a 27 basis point decrease in net interest margins.

Average earning assets increased nine percent and non interest bearing deposits grew a strong 24 percent. Non interest bearing core deposits continue to represent an industry leading 45 percent of total deposits. Our DDA strengths is in an important source of profitability. However, there is a net interest margin impact and a falling rate environment. Since this is a part of our funding base and does not reprice as loan yields decline.

On a linked quarter basis, net interest income declined 3.3 percent or $13.2 million. Two less days in the quarter caused $5 million of the decrease and the remaining $8 million decrease was primarily driven by ac accelerated fee payment partially offset in - by a small amount in average earning assets, and in the fourth quarter a breakage fee on a large fixed rate loan.

Despite these factors, our net interest margin was still a solid 4.53 percent for the quarter. The remix of our loan portfolio continued. In the first quarter, average loans increased 6.4 percent versus the prior year with residential mortgages growing 1.5 billion or 29 percent. Commercial mortgages increased $522 million partially offsetting a decrease in average commercial loans of $902 million.

For the quarter, non interest income was up $26 million or 16 percent due largely to an increase in service charges on deposit accounts and insurance commissions and decreases in auto lease residual write downs and private equity portfolio losses. First quarter non interest expense was up 10 percent year over year. Approximately four percentage points of the increase is attributable to acquisitions to Novus and reconfiguration of our Pacific Northwest branch system network.

On the remaining six percent merit increases and healthcare expenses accounted for four percent. The efficiency ratio for the first quarter was 59.4 percent versus 57.6 percent a year earlier. The efficiency ratio increased primarily due to pressure on net interest incomes stemming from the lower rate environment. The higher efficiency ratio also reflected our recent emphasis on growth in the retail banking and insurance agency businesses.

I'll now address our expectations for the second quarter and full year of 2003. First, we believe that rates will remain relatively stable until the fourth quarter of 2003. Our guidance assumes steepening yield curve in the fourth quarter of the year.

Our current expectation for the second quarter earnings is 87 to 92 cents per share. This guidance is based on the following assumptions in comparison to the first quarter.

First, a modest increase in earning asset with flat loan growth. Second, a five to 10-basis point decline in net interest margin. Third, an approximate five percent increase in non-interest income. Fourth, a one to two percent increase in non-interest expense. Fifth, a provision for credit losses of approximately $30 million. And, finally, an effective tax rate of approximately 34 percent.

We currently expect full-year 2003 earnings per share to be the same as previously stated, in the range of $3.65 to $3.85 per share. Our full year loan loss provision guidance continues to be approximately $120 to $160 million. This results in expected growth in earnings per share between eight percent and 14 percent versus 2002.

This completes our financial overview and guidance. Now on to Phil Flynn, Chief Credit Officer - Phil.

PHILIP FLYNN, UNIONBANCAL CORPORATION, EVP AND CHIEF CREDIT OFFICER: Thanks, David.

Credit results for the first quarter were generally in line with our expectations, with a provision of $30 million and net charge-offs of $53 million. Non-performing assets increased $50 million to $387 million at March 31, driven by the addition of $67 million of aircraft leases to the non-accrual category.

Our reserve for loan losses now totals $586 million, down $23 million from the previous quarter. Within the reserve, the allocation portion is $421 million, while the unallocated is $165 million. Our allowance for credit losses is now 2.21 percent of total loans, and the coverage of non-accrual loans by the allowance is 152 percent.

Let's turn to some specific assets of the portfolio, beginning with the non-performing assets. During the quarter we saw in-flows of non-performing assets of $179 million, up substantially from the previous quarter. The previously-mentioned $67 million of aircraft lease exposures, as well as a $30 million exposure to a Korean trading company, dominated new non-accruals.

We charged off $53 million and were paid down $77 million in the non-performing category. Approximately 75 percent of our non-performers by dollar volume were current at quarter end. As of March 31, we hold $140 million in reserves against the non-performers and have written them down by $165 million from their original balance.

We sold $64 million of non-performing loan commitments during the first quarter. Overall, during the first quarter, the bank sold approximately $98 million of loan commitments in the secondary market at an average of about 82 cents.

As usual, I would like to comment on a few industry-specific portions of our portfolio, beginning with aircraft leasing. We believe that we have acted prudently in moving $67 million of leases to non-accrual. These exposures represent our leases with two companies, one a domestic passenger airline and the other a large cargo company. Our leases with both of these companies are current, and neither company has filed for bankruptcy protection. Nonetheless, we deem it likely that some point this year we will need to renegotiate the terms of our leases with these companies, either inside or outside of bankruptcy and that our value in these leases will likely be impaired.

Thus, we decided to recognize these problems now by moving them to non-accrual and creating large specific reserves against our exposure. Our remaining portfolio of aircraft leases totals less than $50 million and we expect that it will remain relatively healthy in the foreseeable future.

Our commitments to the tower and utilities industry are similar to year-end, with some movement in the sub segments. Total commitments are approximately 3.2 billion. Investment grade is up about 100 million to 1.9 billion. Project financing is about the same at 800 million and non-investment grade is down 100 million to about 500 million.

Over the past two quarters, we have become increasingly comfortable with our power portfolio. The most significant refinancing that affect our portfolio are complete and with those refinancing, we've improved our positions as to both collateral and pricing. Bids in the secondary loan market have firmed dramatically allowing us to reduce some of our exposures at little or not cost.

At this point we have one project financing of less than $20 million on non-accrual, and looking forward, believe that, in the event of further deterioration we may need to move two other loans totaling about 25 million to non-accrual over the next two quarters.

We expect that losses in this portfolio will be limited to between 10 to 20 million this year, in other words, not a meaningful amount. Given our positive view of this portfolio, we have reduced the attribution in our unallocated allowance by 40 percent to approximately $30 million.

Our real estate industry's group portfolio continues to perform very well with commitments of about five billion and vary office exposure down slightly to about 425 million.

Looking forward as David said, we continue to estimate that our loan loss provision for 2003 will be in the range of 120 to 160 million. And we expect the second quarter provision to be approximately 30 million.

Again, it is likely that for the next several quarters, charge-offs will exceed the provision in particular as we recognize additional losses from our aircraft portfolio. However, other than this particularly difficult industry sector, the rest of the portfolio continues to show improve.

With that I'd like to turn the call back to Rick Hartnack.

RICK HARTNACK, UNIONCAL CORPORATION, VICE-CHAIRMAN: Good morning everyone. In my comments this morning I will address some highlights of the first quarter, update you on our acquisition activity, address the marketing and competitive environment, and close with some comments on the California economy.

Obviously, we're pleased with the 22 percent increase in EPS over the first quarter a year ago. We believe this performance continues to reflect solid execution of our strategic business plan.

Let me take a couple minutes to recap some highlights from the first quarter performance. We achieved average non-interest bearing deposits equal to 45 percent of total deposits, up from 41.1 percent a year ago. Our all-in cost of funds fell to 67 basis points. Non-interest income continues to be a source of strength, up 16.3 percent from a year ago and up 11 percent on an annualized basis from last quarter.

Our acquisition efforts continue. First, we completed the integration of Valencia Bank in February and have been doing well. Consumer households and small business clients are all up nicely.

We also continued to enjoy household and business client growth at our First Western acquisition completed last year. The Monterey Bay Bank acquisition was announced last week. Our Denoble (ph) branch expansion continues on pace. We opened one branch and one business banking center in the first quarter. The net result of all of this is net new accounts pace running comfortably ahead of a year ago at the same time.

On the insurance front, we completed the acquisition of Tanner Insurance, giving us the foundation agency we needed in northern California. We now have three significant agencies in major California markets, and we are now pursuing integration strategies, while pushing ahead on franchise growth. In our California middle market segment, new business, new commitments and sales pipelines were all strong, but economy-influenced caution on the part of our borrowers has had our corporate clients at some of the lowest utilization levels we've seen in recent history.

Turning to our capital management strategies, our ability to continue to generate strong earnings has allowed us to both invest for the future and return a meaningful amount of capital to our shareholders. We're investing in our core businesses with distribution, technology and marketing expenditures, while undertaking a series of strategic acquisitions. At the same time, we've offered a competitive dividend and maintain a moderate level of share repurchases.

Our capital levels remain among the strongest in the industry, providing a meaningful cushion against the unexpected, while enabling us to take advantage of opportunities to increase shareholder value when opportunities arise.

Finally, let me take just a quick look at California. Like the nation, we're seeing very modest growth in our economy. And the bulk of the growth is centered in southern California.

So far, this has been growth without much good news in the labor market. And what we see right now is the following: continued strength in the housing sector; reluctance by business to make commitments to expansion; some improvements in prices at the pump, returning disposable income to consumers; no significant negative effects from the state budget deficit yet, but these are expected down the road; and continued recovery in the tech sector. While we're not heavily involved in that sector, its recovery is important to our state.

At this time, we'd be more than happy to take your questions.

OPERATOR: Ladies and Gentlemen, if you do wish to ask a question, please depress one on your touch-tone phone. You will hear a tone indicating you're then placed in queue, and you may remove yourself from queue at any time by depressing the pound key. If you have pressed one prior to this announcement, we ask that you do so again at this time.

If you are using a speakerphone, please pick up a handset before pressing a number. Again, ladies and gentlemen, if you do have a question, please press one at this time.

We do have a question from the line of Mark Lynch with Wellington Management. Please go ahead.

MARK LYNCH, WELLINGTON MANAGEMENT: Good morning. I noticed you've been growing (ph) the loans in the foreign branches fairly rapidly, and I'm wondering what that represents.

DAVID MATSON: Well, Mark, they're up about $200 million. It's the typical trade-related acceptances and that sort of thing. I don't think there's any particular strategy change or anything like that driving it.

MARK LYNCH: But I would have thought that - this is mostly in Asia, I assume?

DAVID MATSON: I would guess. I don't know for sure, but given where most of our activity is, yes.

MARK LYNCH: I would have thought trade relation would be down, so that would represent - if you're getting that much growth, you must be taking it from somebody else.

DAVID MATSON: Maybe. I'm sorry. I just don't know. It's not a big number. (inaudible) it's big.

MARK LYNCH: And the Korean loan, was that a trade finance or a type of loan that you're still making?

DAVID MATSON: No. That Korean loan - we have, as I think I've mentioned before, the international business is almost entirely a correspondent banking trade related business with the exception of some small corporate lending in Korea and Taiwan to the tune of about $100 million.

That $30 million problem comes out of that small piece. It also comes from a customer who's been here since 1988. So it's somewhat surprising.

MARK LYNCH: OK. Thank you.

OPERATOR: We do have a question from the line of Christopher Shenard (ph) with Morgan Stanley. I do apologize for the mispronunciation. Please go ahead.

CHRISTOPHER SHENARD (ph), MORGAN STANLEY: Thank you. Good morning, guys. Christopher Shenard (ph). I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit about interest rate sensitivity and what your position is, you know, as of the end of the quarter? And if you took any actions during the quarter to change your interest rate sensitivity? And then I have a follow up.

DAVID MATSON: Chris (ph), this is David Matson and we have basically not restructured our balance sheet in any major way. We have ongoing alcove activities, which reflects our philosophy of having stable net interest income in that we continue to reposition our derivatives and other protection that we buy as well as change our securities position, but no material change.

CHRISTOPHER SHENARD (ph): OK. And to follow up, I was wondering if you could refresh our memory in terms of what your escrow deposits were last quarter and a year ago and what they were this quarter?

DAVID MATSON: Certain, Chris (ph). At the bank wide level, title escrow of deposits - and by the way, the ones I'm quoting are demand deposits. What we call non-interest bearing deposits and that's where we make the majority of our money.

And at the end of the first quarter we're at about 2.6 billion. A year ago it was about 1.8 and at last quarter it was 2.9. And it's at the end of the fourth quarter it was about 2.9. And it is a seasonal business comparing it first quarter to fourth quarter.

OPERATOR: Again, ladies and gentlemen, if you do have a question please press one at this time. We do have a question from the line of Robert Lacoursiere with Lehman Brothers. Please go ahead.

ROBERT LACOURSIERE, LEHMAN BROTHERS: Yes. I wonder given the fact that insurance commission line is becoming more important and looks like it will continue to become more important, if you could refresh our memories on the seasonality of it and your expectation of the underlying organic growth rates.

DAVID MATSON: Yes. Let me make a couple of comments and we may have to provide some additional color for you later. But it's not a terribly seasonal business in terms of the revenue, but it's seasonal in terms of the business activity.

There are couple of periods in the year where there's more renewal activity going on. Having said that, I think that the organic growth in the near term is going to continue to follow the industry pricing inflation which is diminishing from its high point last year. We were in, you know, kind of strong - I think all of us were seeing strong double digit inflation in insurance premiums. That's certainly going to abate, and, you know, our business model is based on being able to deal with that diminution in growth in the individual premiums over time.

ROBERT LACOURSIERE: Thank you.

OPERATOR: We do have a question from the line of Campbell Chaney with Sanders Morris Harris. Please go ahead.

CAMPBELL CHANEY, SANDERS MORRIS HARRIS GROUP: Thanks, and good morning.

Phil, I got distracted. I think you mentioned in one of the industry segments of the portfolio two loans of $25 million that could go non-performing. What category was that from?

PHILIP FLYNN: No, it was -- I was talking about -- I was trying to size the potential problem in Power and Utilities, and, first of all, the overall point I was making is it's not much of a problem, in our opinion.

CAMPBELL CHANEY: OK.

PHILIP FLYNN: Looking forward, as we sit today -- in fact, going back to the fourth quarter -- we had one project financing of less than 20 million on non-accrual. And our best guess is, given further deterioration, there could be two more projects that total 25 between the two of them that could go to non-accrual.

CAMPBELL CHANEY: OK. Now, that clarifies it. And then, something else -- I think you mentioned the write-downs -- again, this is for clarification -- you've written down your non-performing loans 165 million. So, of the 386 and a half million, that's net of the 165, I take it?

PHILIP FLYNN: Right. Yeah, you add the 165 back to the 387 we have today; those were the original amounts.

CAMPBELL CHANEY: OK. Now, that's significant write-downs.

PHILIP FLYNN: Yes.

CAMPBELL CHANEY: That's all I had; those are my only clarifications. Thanks a lot.

PHILIP FLYNN: Thank you, Campbell.

OPERATOR: We do have a question from the line of Gary Townsend with Friedman Billings Ramsey. Please go ahead.

GARY TOWNSEND, FRIEDMAN BILLINGS RAMSEY & CO.: Good morning.

David, could you give -- or are you giving any guidance with respect to where you see margin in coming quarters?

DAVID MATSON: Gary, we provided guidance for the second quarter, and it's been our policy not to provide guidance past that.

GARY TOWNSEND: I'm sorry, could I ask you to repeat, I guess, what that guidance is for the NIM (ph)?

DAVID MATSON: Sure. Let me get for you here in a second. We have -- for the second quarter, we're expecting net interest -- excuse me -- margin to drop between five to 10 basis points.

GARY TOWNSEND: Thank you, again.

DAVID MATSON: Certainly.

OPERATOR: We do have a question from the line of Jim Arverell (ph) with Wellington Management. Please go ahead.

JIM ARVERELL (ph), WELLINGTON MANAGEMENT: Hi. I was wondering if you could flesh out your thinking on the Monterey Bank acquisition.

DAVID MATSON: Because this transaction is in registration, we are not able to comment about it at this time.

OPERATOR: Again, ladies and gentlemen, if you do have a question, please press one at this time.

We do have a question from the line of Joe Morford with RBC. Please go ahead.

JOSEPH MORFORD, ANALYST, RBC CAPITAL MARKETS: Thanks. Good morning.

I guess, David, could you comment on your expectations for deposit growth through yearend, and any plans you have to increase the investment portfolio? Thanks.

DAVID MATSON: Well, we continue -- we expect that -- hold on for one second, Joe.

JOSEPH MORFORD: Sure.

DAVID MATSON: I've got a slide here -- well, not a slide, but a -- let me take a quick shot at the deposit growth. Just the underlying piece of deposit is continuing to build the franchise. And between the acquisition plans that we've discussed in the past and that are, that have been announced and our core organic growth in households and business units, we think we set the foundation for solid deposit growth that, you know, as you look forward, I think the blistering pace that we had a year ago is probably not in the cards for this year.

JOSEPH MORFORD: Right. OK.

DAVID MATSON: And kind of put a little bit of color on that in terms of high-level numbers. We've not provided guidance on this issue, but we think that that is, that in the wholesale side, it'll be a mixture. We think that business DDA will continue to grow and title escrow will be pretty flat through the year we believe.

And Rick did the retail side of it. We've not put numbers against it Joe (ph).

JOSEPH MORFORD: OK. And what about investment portfolios? Should we expect that to grow if loans are, if loan growth is slowing

DAVID MATSON: That's where we're going to end up putting them. We'd love to get more loans that we like, but on a risk-adjusted basis, we're being cautious right now.

JOSEPH MORFORD: OK, thanks very much.

OPERATOR: We do have a question from the line of Roz Looby with First Boston. Please go ahead.

ROZ LOOBY, FIRST BOSTON: Thanks. Good morning. Phil I have a question for you on the in-flows and the NPAs (ph). I believe you said they were $179 million. You know, of that, you mentioned that 67 raises in the 39 to the Korean Company. That leaves about $80 million, which is more than I think you had in in-flows all last quarter. Can you talk about what that $80 million? Is it more middle market? Is there some geographic characterization you can give to it? And then I have a follow-up question. Thanks.

PHILIP FLYNN: Sure. You know, between the leases and the Korean company, that's 100 of it.

ROZ LOOBY: Yes.

PHILIP FLYNN: I forget what we're last quarter. It was pretty close to that. There was nothing real significant. We had one addition new non-accrual of more than 20 million, which was for a timber company. After that it gets pretty small and pretty scattered. So you know, really absent the aircraft leases and this Korean thing, it really was a pretty moderate amount of in-flows I believe.

ROZ LOOBY: Could they be characterized more as middle market versus large corporate or do you not have a sense?

PHILIP FLYNN: No, I have it here, hang on, let me just eyeball the list. You know, I wouldn't really, there's, just looking at it, there's a few small middle market companies. There's media company for maybe 10 million, cable company for five. It looks like most of it did not come out of the California middle market. It was odds and ends from some of the old specialty groups or national banking.

ROZ LOOBY: Thanks. I have a similar question, you mentioned you filled, I think it was 65 million our of non-performing during the quarter?

PHILIP FLYNN: Yes.

ROZ LOOBY: Is that correct? And was that largely power lines, you mentioned that pricing has gone back there.

PHILIP FLYNN: Well no, because I didn't have very much in non-performers.

ROZ LOOBY: Oh, OK.

PHILIP FLYNN: As far as, most of that, we sold some telecom exposure about 40 of that was telecom.

ROZ LOOBY: OK.

PHILIP FLYNN: The secondary market has firmed up pretty well and you would notice overall we sold almost $100 million, which is more than we sold I think in any quarter last year. We're continuing that pace right now as well. I just believe that with the market firming, we should take advantage of that to exit some of these segments and names that we don't.

ROZ LOOBY: Sure. Thanks very much.

OPERATOR: We do have a question from the line of Brian Harvey with Fox-Pitt Kelton. Please go ahead.

BRIAN HARVEY, FOX-PITT KELTON, INC.: Thank you. Just a couple of questions. First, on the insurance recovery, is that $3.3 million net of expenses? And the second question, just following up on the last one, is, Phil, can you just give a little better characterization of the middle market credit out there, what you're seeing today in California and if there's been any change over the last six months?

JACK RICE: Why don't I answer that one first. Our middle market portfolio - and I think I've mentioned this before - is very seasoned. It's not a particularly leveraged portfolio. And most of our companies I would characterize as having hunkered down to get through this economic cycle. So I haven't really seen a lot of movement there. Not just the last six months, but even, you know, going back a year or two.

We just haven't had a lot of problems out of that portfolio. We also haven't had a lot of new borrowing out of the portfolio, which is unfortunate. But from a credit quality point of view, it hasn't been an issue.

BRIAN HARVEY: Has there been any difference between northern and southern California?

JACK RICE: You know, maybe anecdotally a little bit. But the fact is that so much more of our portfolio is in southern California it's hard to draw that distinction. And we're not a big tech player, so we really didn't get caught up in that.

PHILIP FLYNN: Brian, to answer the first question, the insurance was a business interruption and there were no costs against it.

BRIAN HARVEY: OK. Thank you.

OPERATOR: We do have a question from the line of David Stumpf with A.G. Edwards. Please go ahead.

DAVID STUMPF, A.G. EDWARDS & SONS: Good morning. Guys, can you all comment at all on the - any potential impact that this Wal-Mart visa litigation might have on your card processing on merchant banking fees? I know it's a big unknown as to what the outcome may be, and I know these are big line items. But could that have any impact on your numbers there?

DAVID MATSON: I think it would be premature for us to guess. And your characterization of it not being a hugely significant issue at our bank is probably accurate. I think those cases have got a long way to go as they win their way through the court system. But I think anything else would be improper on our part.

DAVID STUMPF: OK - thanks.

OPERATOR: Again, ladies and gentlemen, if you do have a question, please press one at this time. We do have a question from the line of Christopher Shenard (ph) with Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead.

CHRISTOPHER SHENARD (ph): Hi, guys. I was just wondering if you could add a little more detail around your comment on commercial loan utilization being near historic lows. You know where is it today, and kind of where has it been historically? And, you now, just how big is the range? And, also, if you could talk about, you know, what you think it would take for utilization to start to rise again?

JACK RICE: Sure. You know it's hard to give a lot of historical information. It's not something that we've tracked over time.

But just as an example, today, in the commercial loan book, we have about $10.5 billion of loan outstanding throughout the whole bank. And we have commitments of about just over $20 billion. So utilization is around 50 percent.

That strikes us, as we think back over the last few years, as fairly low. I'm guessing that utilization might have averaged more like 60 percent or so historically. But you know I don't have exact numbers going back.

And you know, clearly, in the sweet spot of our commercial lending, which is the middle market and corporate bank here in California, I think companies need to feel more comfortable about their outlook for the economy before they start making investments require them to borrow money.

CHRISTOPHER SHENARD (ph): Do you also think that, you know, the budget situation has to be resolved before these smaller businesses get more confidence?

DAVID MATSON: Yes. I think that the budget situation at the state level and indeed all the economic discussion around the circumstances at the national level are just one additional brick in the pack of lack of confidence for the business guy. And it seems like we just move from one story of uncertainty to another and that's a part of it.

You know, when we did our small business survey earlier in the year, the condition of the state government came up as a major concern. You know, it manifests itself in a lot of different ways for individual businesses but, you know, it's an uncertainty factor. Unfortunately one of many and until confidence builds, it's going to be a hard go for loan demand.

I think not only here in California, but all across the country. I think you're hearing that from a lot of banks like ours.

CHRISTOPHER SHENARD (ph): Great. Thank you.

OPERATOR: Gentlemen, there are no further questions. Please continue.

JACK RICE: Well if there are no further questions, thank you very much for joining us on this call and any follow up can be directed to me in the investor relations department.

Thank you very much.

OPERATOR: Ladies and gentlemen, this conference will be available for replay after 12 p.m. noon today Pacific time through Thursday, April 24 at 12 midnight. You may access the AT&T executive teleconference service at any time by dialing 1-800-475-6701 and entering the access code of 678808.

International participants may dial 320-365-3844. Those numbers again are a 1-800-475-6701 and 320-365-3844, with the access code of 678808. That does conclude our conference for today. Thank you for your participation and for using AT&T executive teleconference service.

You may now disconnect.

urn:contentItem:58BD-TYN1-DXH2-627D-00000-00Q1 2013 NYSE Euronext Earnings Conference Call - Final2013-04-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:33ZLexisNexis043013a5027392.792Q1 2013 NYSE EuronextEarnings Conference Call - Final

Corporate Participants

* Stephen Davidson

NYSE Euronext- VP of IR

* Duncan Niederauer

NYSE Euronext- CEO

* Michael Geltzeiler

NYSE Euronext- EVP and CFO

* Larry Leibowitz

NYSE Euronext- COO

Conference Call Participants

* Richard Repetto

Sandler O'Neill & Partners - Analyst

* Howard Chen

Credit Suisse - Analyst

* Chris Allen

Evercore - Analyst

* Alex Kramm

UBS - Analyst

* Niamh Alexander

Keefe, Bruyette & Woods - Analyst

Presentation

OPERATOR: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the first quarter 2013 NYSE Euronextearnings conference call. My name is Caroline and I will be your operator today. At this time all participants are in a listen-only mode. We will be facilitating a question-and-answer session towards the end of this conference. (Operator Instructions).

I would now like to turn the call over to Stephen Davidson, Head of Investor Relations at NYSE Euronext. Please go ahead, sir.

STEPHEN DAVIDSON, VP OF IR, NYSE EURONEXT: Thanks, Caroline. Good morning and welcome to the NYSE Euronextfirst-quarter 2013 earnings conference call.

Before I introduce today's speakers let me remind you that comments on the call may contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act. These statements are based on NYSE Euronextcurrent expectations and involve risks and uncertainties that could cause NYSE Euronextactual results to differ materially from those in the statements. These forward-looking statements speak as of today and you should not rely on them as representing our views in the future.

Please refer to our SEC filings for a full discussion of the risk factors that may affect any forward-looking statements. Except for any obligation to disclose material information under the Federal Securities Laws, NYSE Euronextundertakes no obligation to release publicly any revisions to any forward-looking statements to reflect events or circumstances after this conference call.

We will discuss non-GAAP financial measures during this call. These non-GAAP measures are fully reconciled in the tables attached to the text of the earnings press release that we issued earlier today. We believe that these tables provide investors useful information about our business trends. However, our non-GAAP measures do not replace and are not superior to GAAP measures.

Duncan Niederauer, Chief Executive Officer, will review the highlights for the quarter, update you on key developments in our businesses and conclude with an update on the acquisition by ICE. Michael Geltzeiler, Chief Financial Officer, will then review the financial results for the quarter. We will then open the line for your questions. Also in the room for the Q&A session is a Larry Leibowitz, Chief Operating Officer.

We are incorporating slides for the call today which are available for viewing on our website and Duncan and Mike will refer to the slides during their remarks.

With that let me turn the call over to Duncan.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER, CEO, NYSE EURONEXT: Thanks, Stephen. Good morning, everybody, and thanks for joining today's call. I will begin my prepared remarks on slide four.

In the first quarter, we benefited from the actions that we have taken over the past several quarters to improve the fundamental earnings power of the Company. We saw improved trading volumes in our European derivatives franchise and launched new products. We are on track to transition our UK clearing to ICE Clear Europe by the end of June and we are focused on realizing the value of our continental derivatives clearing after the first quarter of 2014.

We are continuing to see strong momentum in our listings business achieving a 75% market share of tech IPOs in the first quarter on the heels of last year's similarly excellent results.

We are beginning to generate incremental revenue from our new market data agreements. We have continued to reduce our expenses and are on track to exceed our full-year 2013 guidance. And lastly, the reduction in our share count and other capital management actions we have taken are beginning to have a meaningful impact on earnings.

The macro backdrop as I noted on our last call continues to show encouraging signs for the global economy so I'm optimistic that we are on a slow trend up punctuated by event-driven volatility along the way.

In the meantime we are continuing to execute against our Project 14 commitments to our shareholders and also preparing for our combination with ICE which I will go into in more detail on later slides.

The net result of all of this is that we reported $0.57 a share on $600 million in revenue this quarter which represents a 21% increase in earnings year over year and a 33% increase quarter over quarter. So in summary we are pleased with our results and we are looking to build momentum as we move through 2013 and into our proposed combinations with ICE.

Please turn to slide five. Slide five is familiar to all of you and illustrates the strong progress we have made in executing against our strategy. As you can see from this slide, we are not taking our foot off the gas. I will highlight a couple of initiatives on the growth side first.

We are launching new derivatives products. In our Liffe Business, we continue to move out on the yield curve. Remember our Liffe business in the UK has historically been almost entirely focused on the short end of the curve so we have continued to expand with the mid curve options that we launched last year and the Swapnote products that we are now offering which move us further out onto the yield curve. Once we are in the ICE clearing house in the second half of this year, expect to see us launch even more new products.

Next, we continue to be very focused on maintaining the position we enjoy in the capital formation and listings business. We were number one in 2011, we were number one in 2012, and we are off to a terrific start this year. The success we had last year winning 80% of the big tech deals has continued into 2013 and given the pipeline we can see and the deals we know we have already won some of which have not been made public yet, we believe that this will continue.

Lastly, we are about to see the result of having revamped all of our global market data agreements and launching some new products in that business. All of these growth initiatives are complemented by our accomplishments on the efficiency and capital management fronts which positively impacted our results this quarter.

Please turn to slide six. Slide six provides an update of our FICC businesses. We saw a nice rebound in NYSELiffe volumes in the first quarter which were up 36% year-over-year with FICC product volume in Europe up 53% when compared with the same period last year.

In the upper left quadrant, our flagship Euribor futures contracts registered an all-time high in trading volumes and ADV for the first quarter of 2013 was 1.2 million contracts, an 82% increase from the last quarter.

The surge in volume was driven by a number of key events in the Eurozone including early LTR repayments by banks to the ECB in February, uncertainty surrounding the Italian elections and the Cypress bailout as well as heightened expectations of a potential rate cut.

Euribor options also showed even stronger growth this quarter driven by the continued success of our innovative mid-curve option products which reached an ADV of 680,000 contracts, a 143% increase from the fourth quarter.

The aforementioned euro Swapnote product which has been a focus for growth has had a solid start to the year. Year-to-date Swapnote volume has traded $27 billion of notional and by way of reference the CME swap future has traded $19 billion of notional year to date.

Among other products, Gilts in the upper right-hand quadrant of the slide continue to benefit from quantitative easing by the Bank of England. In the lower left-hand quadrant, you can see that in our LiffeUS business we have seen positive volume growth and open interest trends for the first quarter in the MSCI product suite with ADV up 89% year-over-year and open interest up 119% year-over-year.

Momentum also continues to build for futures on the DTCC GCF Repo Index as shown in the lower right-hand quadrant of the slide. We experienced record volume days in January and average daily volume is up 56% sequentially.

Before moving away from the FICC business, I wanted to reiterate our stance on clearing for our UK derivatives business. We are on track as discussed previously to transition to ICE Clear Europe at the end of the second quarter. All of our regulatory filings have been submitted. The technology build has been completed and in May we expect to step up our technology integration and member testing.

Please turn to slide seven. Slide seven provides you with selected updates in our equity derivatives businesses. First on the left hand side of the slide, let's talk about US options. In January 2013, the NYSE AMEX options and NYSE ARCA options complex reached their highest monthly combined equity options market share to date of 29.4%. We were also the first options exchange to receive SEC approval to begin trading many options a product designed for the retail investor which we launched on March 18.

Product innovation and development continue to be a focus and in the first quarter we were able to secure a semi-exclusive licensing agreement with the Russell Index Group. These products began trading this month.

On the right-hand side of the slide, we talk about our FTSE equity derivatives franchise. This franchise provided a strong start to the first quarter with volumes up 29% year-over-year. The increase in volumes saw a return to trading in our core FTSE derivatives franchise. The FTSE 100 Index options were up 86% versus the same period last year and the combined open interest for the FTSE franchise stood 13% above 2012 levels.

Please turn to slide eight. Slide eight provides you with a snapshot of our cash equities business taking a particular look at trading volumes and net trading revenue. Over the past few years our objective in the cash trading businesses has been to focus on profitability and stabilizing market share. In Europe we have maintained our share at around 65% and pricing has been relatively stable.

In the US, we have opportunistically looked for ways to increase pricing which has helped to soften the impact of declines in trading volumes and the growth in off exchange trading which has impacted our market share.

Before moving on to the next slide, I want to address two important issues impacting these businesses. The financial transaction tax in Europe and off exchange trading in the US. First, let's talk about the state of play with regard to the FTP.

As many of you may recall the Commission issued a proposal on February 14 for a broad-based tax on equities, equity like products, derivatives, bonds and others which only applies to those member states but could have extraterritorial impact.

In terms of the Enhanced Cooperation Group, there is no agreement between the 11 countries as to how the tax will be collected, on what products it should be collected or how the proceeds would be used. In fact several heads of national debt management agencies including France and Italy have publicly warned that the FTT could push up yield spreads and increase borrowing costs. Given all of these, issues, the Commission's implementation date of January 1, 2014 seems optimistic.

It continues to be our view that this tax as currently outlined would likely destabilize the European financial markets, negatively impact returns and increase fees for average investors and mutual fund owners, exactly the wrong policy at the wrong time.

Any policy measure that has the direct effect of draining liquidity from the capital markets is a measure that will hurt European entrepreneurs especially the SMEs that so desperately need to access the markets to finance their growth. But given that this dialogue continues, it bears watching.

Shifting to the US with regard to off exchange trading, off exchange trading reached a record level of 36% in the first quarter of 2013, up from 34% in the fourth quarter. To be clear we think that this is not just about dark pools. Dark pools are only a third of off exchange trading, the other two-thirds is internalization.

While we think there is a place for alternative execution venues, we worry about the aggregate effect of off exchange activity on market quality and question whether the pendulum has swung too far. As such we plan to continue raising awareness with regard to our market quality concerns and we will also continue our level the playing field advocacy efforts here in the US.

We are looking forward to working closely with Mary Jo White, the new Chair of the SEC. Mary Jo has a stellar reputation. She understands the issues that we face with the fragmentation of our markets and I am confident that we will be able to work together as an industry with the regulators to improve market quality.

Please turn to slide nine. On slide nine, we show the continued momentum in our listings franchise. We rank number one in IPOs year to date 2013 and follow on proceeds globally raising $12.1 billion in total global proceeds from 26 IPOs and $48.3 billion in total global proceeds from 140 follow-on offerings in the first quarter of 2013.

In the US, we led the market with 17 IPOs excluding closed-end funds and continued to capture the majority of technology-based IPOs. We saw larger deal sizes from larger companies coming to the market. Private equity backed companies which made up about 35% of the market year to date, carveouts and yield oriented deals drove the volume in the first quarter. We listed six of the eight private equity backed IPOs in the first quarter which raised a total of $1.8 billion or 68% of all proceeds from private equity backed IPOs.

In Europe, we welcomed six companies to our markets including Infosys which was the first company to be admitted to trading on our markets in London, Paris and New York.

Please turn to slide 10. Slide 10 outlines the new strategic paradigm for the technology business that we introduced last quarter. While the market continues to be challenging for technology sales as you saw in our first quarter results, the market demand for disruptive technology is increasing and we have also increased our dialogue with global trading organizations regarding game changing service offerings, the hosting of matching engines, and open connectivity to global markets.

The trading community is becoming even more focused on cost optimization and is looking to us as a trusted partner to provide innovative ways to improve their trading infrastructure models.

Regulatory obligations continue to increase resulting in additional assets required to be traded on exchange. NYSE Technologies is working closely with customers to address these needs throughout our product and solutions suite. NYSE Technologies has the datacenter and solution set to be well positioned to take advantage of this industry shift.

So how was this shift in paradigm translating into results? Our client, the Warsaw Stock Exchange, successfully completed its migration of its cash and derivatives markets to UTP and connected to our safety network which will extend their reach across NYSE Euronextglobal market data and trading infrastructure.

In terms of our large scale infrastructure hosting capabilities, we are working with several global trading organizations to provide comprehensive trading infrastructure managed services. These are large recurring revenue transactions.

We launched the best trades and quotes market data product which provides substantial cost savings to retail brokerage firms and wealth management organizations who require access to level one data products. And lastly, we are beginning to generate incremental market data revenue that will build through the second half of 2013 and we have significant plans for our super feed business that will begin to generate additional revenue in the second half as well.

Before I move onto the next slide, I wanted to address the recent media coverage of our NYXP business. John Robson and the leader of that business has strengthened his leadership team which is focused on executing against the strategic vision I just outlined. At the same time, we are working with ICE to explore how we will leverage this important business capability in the new organization post merger.

As we look to expand our capabilities for clients we regularly have discussions with potential partners, clients and industry participants to explore new opportunities to deliver best-in-class solutions for our trading community. We have always conducted these partnership discussions and we will continue to have discussions with partners now and in the future, both traditional and nontraditional. We have an exciting business with significant potential that we will continue to drive forward.

Please turn to slide 11. The next two slides focus on the transaction with ICE. Slide 11 is a quick review of the compelling nature of the combination. When you look at the combined business you see a company with a completely different complexion than the one we have today. The cash trading segment which is arguably the most competitive and commoditized part of our business generated 7% of our revenues in the US and 9% in Europe in 2012. This combined 16% will decline to around 10% of the combined company and even less after the envisioned IPO of Euronext.

The more lucrative and competitively stronger derivatives business which is 26% of our revenues in 2012 would increase to 44% of the revenue base for the new company. Most importantly, almost 50% of our pro forma net revenue will be generated from our derivatives businesses. This is a critical aspect of the transaction because of the relatively high margin and its impact on our overall valuation.

We are excited about the potential and remain confident that our companies can unlock significant value and growth, a confidence the market seems to share. We believe the change will be a constant in our industry for some time to come and our combination brings the experience, assets and leadership together that is necessary to drive sustainable growth for our investors and our clients.

Please turn to slide 12 which will be my last slide before I turn it over to Mike.

We put this slide in the deck because we have gotten a lot of questions about next steps in the transaction timeline and we thought we would lay it out for everybody on this slide. We are currently working on two parallel tracks, one focused on the competition approval process and the other on general transaction requirements that are needed to close the deal.

On the competition side, we have completed the US process with the DOJ under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act and we are now focusing on the European requirements. Last week we received the official referral of the competition review for the European commission from the United Kingdom, Portugal and Spain so we are now working towards the completion of our notification of the Commission known as Form CO which will serve as the basis for the competition review.

Upon the receipt of our notification, the European Commission will begin Phase 1 which is a 25 business day review process. If an in depth investigation of the transaction is required, so-called Phase 2, that would start a 90-day clock after that.

As we've learned in the past the timelines for these review processes are not guaranteed and are just guiding principles and are subject to further extensions based on circumstances but we've already made good progress. Our Form S-4 has been filed with the SEC and has been deemed effective by the SEC as of today and on the back of that, both companies, both we and ICE have set the date for the shareholder vote on June 3.

We still believe that this transaction will be finalized in the second half of this year.

Our conversations are also ongoing with all stakeholders involved with the IPO of Euronext which we expect will follow soon after the closing of the primary transaction. We will continue to be transparent about the process and keep you updated on key milestones and developments.

With that, I would now like to pass the call over to Mike for a review of the first quarter's financial results.

MICHAEL GELTZEILER, EVP AND CFO, NYSE EURONEXT: Thanks, Duncan, and good morning. Slide 13 provides comparative GAAP results for the first quarter of 2013. Our GAAP EPS was $0.52 per share which compares favorably to the $0.34 per share we reported in Q1 2012. Our non-GAAP EPS of $0.57 per share reflects two primary adjustments this quarter as reconciled in the schedule.

In the quarter we reported an $8 million charge for merger expenses and exit costs primarily related to the ICE transaction. The other item was a $10 million pretax charge to fair value outstanding restricted stock awards resulting from the increase in our stock price. Following recent shareholder approval of our amended plan, outstanding restricted stock awards will again be fixed in value under equity settled accounting worlds.

As a result, equity compensation costs in the second quarter of 2013 will decline by $10 million, hence the adjustment. After adjusting for these items, we derived non-GAAP EPS of $0.57 per share.

My review of our financial results from this point forward will exclude the impact of merger expenses, exit costs, the stock-based compensation charge I discussed and discrete tax items.

Slide 14 provides our non-GAAP financial results for the quarter. Net revenues of $600 million on a reported basis were in line with the first quarter of 2012 but up 7% versus the fourth quarter. The increase quarter over quarter was driven by higher volumes in our global derivatives businesses.

Reported costs were lower by $25 million or 6% driving a 12% growth in operating income. Diluted share count declined by 15 million shares year-over-year from our 2012 share repurchase plan which helped drive EPS growth to 21% for the quarter.

Slides 15 and 16 detail the financial performance for our derivatives segment. Derivatives revenue in the first quarter was $201 million, higher by 14% year-over-year and up 26% sequentially attributable to a strong pickup in trading volume.

Euribor future volumes in particular increased 82% while both ARCA and MX Options reported growth in both market share and ADD. The revenue growth on flat costs helped boost EBITDA margins to 56%.

Derivatives accounted for 34% of our consolidated net revenues and 43% of our operating income. Revenue capture for NYSELiffe was lower year-over-year and quarter-over-quarter attributed primarily to clients hitting volume tiers with the increase in volumes. Capture for the US options business was higher year-over-year and quarter-over-quarter driven by positive mix.

Similarly, slides 17 and 18 show the financial performance for our cash trading and listing segment. Cash trading and listings accounted for 48% of our consolidated net revenues and 47% of our operating income in the first quarter. Cash trading and listings net revenue was $287 million in the first quarter of 2013, down 6% versus the prior year period but up 2% compared to the fourth quarter of 2012.

European cash market share across our four primary markets which excludes off exchange trading volume was 65% in the first quarter up from 64% in the prior year.

In US cash equities, our market share across all tapes declined 120 basis points both year-over-year and quarter-over-quarter. Off exchange traded share increased to 36% of the US equities markets, up from 34% in the prior year.

[Global] listings revenues including governance services which we report in other revenues is up 9% in the first quarter. Revenue capture for US cash increased to $0.043 per 100 shares handled for Q1 above the $0.042 recorded in the first quarter of 2012 and the $0.040 in Q4. The incremental increase in capture is due to volume mix and minor pricing adjustments on NYSE ARCO.

Revenue capture for European cash on a per transaction basis increased to $0.62 in Q1 2013 from $0.57 in Q1 2012 and $0.58 in Q4 2012. The increase year-over-year was driven by an increase in trade size and a decision to reduce listing fees for European warrants and increase trading fees.

Slide 19 details the financial performance for our information services and technology solutions segment. Information services and technology solutions accounted for 19% of our net revenue and 10% of our operating income in the first quarter of 2013. Segment revenue was $112 million, a decrease of $9 million from Q1 prior year and a decrease of $8 million sequentially.

As Duncan mentioned earlier, the sales shortfalls were attributed to the absence of any significant new managed services sales whereas the prior quarter had large sales with Russell and ATG in Q4 and Warsaw in Q1 prior year.

The environment continues to be challenging so we believe this business is well positioned to leverage the industry's focus on cost optimization and changing infrastructure models.

With the new global market data agreements in place, we expect to see technology services revenue growth to accelerate in the back half of 2013. These incremental revenues will begin in Q2 and are expected to grow as the year progresses.

Slide 20 provides you with the progress we have made with our Project 14 cost efficiency program. Over the past 12 months, we have reported total operating expenses of [$1,553 million which is $113 million] (corrected by company after the call) below the 2011 base level of $1,666 million. Adjusting for currency rates and portfolio changes and discreet investments of $49 million, we arrive at an annualized expense base of [$1,519 million] (corrected by company after the call) through the first quarter of 2013 which is [$147 million] (corrected by company after the call) below our 2011 starting point or [59% of the total $250 million] (corrected by company after the call) to be saved by the end of 2014.

You'll recall that our commitment for P14 savings was originally 65% of the $250 million by the end 2013 so we are well on our way to exceed this target.

Based on the positive development of expenses in the first quarter and a series of savings initiatives planned for this year including the $15 million we expect to save in the second half of 2013 with our move to ICE Clear Europe, we now expect our full-year 2013 reported expenses to be less than $1,525 million.

Slide 21 details our cash and debt position as of the end of March. Gross debt at March 29 was $2.5 billion. This is basically the same level of debt we had at year end as we did not have any variable debt that we could pay down with our excess cash from the quarter. Our cash balances grew by $147 million in the quarter. In June we plan to retire the remaining $414 million of 4.8% US notes.

Our debt to EBITDA leverage ratio decreased to 2.3 times on stronger EBITDA generation. Had we been able to use our excess cash to retire debt, leverage would have been reduced to 2.2 times for the quarter.

Capital expenditures were $27 million in the quarter, well within our guidance of less than $150 million for the full year and last week the Board declared a $0.30 quarterly cash dividend for the second quarter of 2013 which is payable on June 28.

Now I would like to turn the call back to Duncan for closing remarks.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: Thanks, Mike. So in closing, the first quarter was a very strong start for us in 2013. We saw a rebound in trading volumes in our European derivatives franchise and we launched some new products. We are on track to transition our UK derivatives business clearing to ICE Clear in Europe by the end of Q2. Our listings franchise continued to build momentum by maintaining a number one global leadership position and achieving a dominant market share of technology IPOs.

We expect to begin seeing the positive revenue impact of our new market data agreements in the current quarter. And lastly, our costs are on track to exceed our full-year 2013 cost guidance.

While we are executing against our Project 14 commitments, we are also well into the integration planning and regulatory approval processes of our combination with ICE and the next milestone for that combination will be the shareholder meetings on June 3.

With that we will take a few questions from all of you. Thanks for listening.

Questions and Answers

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions). Richard Repetto, Sandler O'Neill.

RICHARD REPETTO, ANALYST, SANDLER O'NEILL & PARTNERS: Good morning, guys. I guess the first question, Duncan, comes from your remarks on market quality. We know or at least it was reported in the media you have met with the SEC with some of the other exchange heads. I think I am aware of you meeting with even some companies as well. But when you talked about what are the remedies if one-third of the TRF volume is -- it looks like you are pointing towards the wholesalers, the other two thirds. What are the remedies besides a trade out rule that you see could bring back the market quality you're talking about?

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: I will start, Rich, and then I will let Leibo add to it as well. So we realize it is a complicated question. This didn't happen overnight. Our point that we keep trying to focus on is that it isn't just about dark pools. If we are talking about dark pools and those are block crossing networks that provide us significantly better customer experience that the public market may not be able to provide, I think there has to be a place for those in market structure in the US.

I think our bigger concern and to be clear we think it is going to have to be a combination of things that would get done. I don't think there is one single thing that would necessarily enhance the market quality but we feel like there is a degradation in market quality, the darker individual stocks seem to get the wider the spread seems to get. We don't think that is a -- we don't think that is a healthy trend and whether it is talking about some kind of a trade out rule that simply requires an internalizer to improve the customer experience in either size or price, the way they have done in Canada and are talking about doing it in Australia or thinking about a rethink of the access fees, there is a whole host of things that could be done.

We realize it took us a long time to get here, it is going to take us a while to kind of reverse the trend if it is even possible but I am encouraged by the fact that a lot of people are at least willing to come to the table to talk about it.

We are meeting with investors, we are meeting with a number of sell-side firms. We are all meeting together and having roundtables to talk about is there a better solution that would be better for the end clients and I am cautiously optimistic. Leibo, what would you add to that?

LARRY LEIBOWITZ, COO, NYSE EURONEXT: I think it is a pretty good summary. I just think that if you add up all the regulatory changes made over the last 10 years they have sort of caused just a natural competitive force that will drive more and more volume off exchange as other parties get more and more sophisticated about segmenting customer flow or recirculating flow before it gets to an exchange so that what gets to the exchange is lower and lower quality. And I think what we are really concerned about is it is not our market share. It is about what is the quality of the flow that comes to the exchange, how wide do the spreads get? Those sorts of things.

That is our main concern and we understand that this is going to be a balancing act where exchanges are going to have to give something and we are going to have to put this together in a piece that it makes natural sense for competition to find the right level.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: Right, and look, we expect everyone to defend their business model and people should expect us to defend the same (inaudible). Right? Everyone is doing what they should do. So I think we are going to remaining engaged in this dialogue and we are happy to sit down with everybody and put other things on the table too if that is what it takes to strike the right compromise. Okay. Thanks.

RICHARD REPETTO: Got it. Thank you.

OPERATOR: Howard Chen, Credit Suisse.

HOWARD CHEN, ANALYST, CREDIT SUISSE: Good morning, everyone. Just with respect to the new global market data agreements coming into place, is your expectation still that the incremental revenue opportunity is about 10% additive on a full run rate? And if use and terminal count continue to trend a bit lower, how much does that eat into the potential upside?

MICHAEL GELTZEILER: I will take the first part of that. In terms of the run rate, we have previously said that we expect the series of changes, the new products that we are launching, the price increases and the restructuring of the global data agreements including addressing the non-display access to generate a double-digit growth. Yes.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: I think it is hard to predict where that trend is going to go. Remember that that is an overall industry issue. It impacts the size of the entire CPA pie not just specifically us but we are sort of dealing with that by being more aggressive, or balanced I would say in how we charge for non-display and the proprietary products we sell ourselves because we are developing a lot more of these proprietary products. So we expect that that would offset those things.

HOWARD CHEN: Understood. Thanks, Larry. Thanks, Mike.

OPERATOR: Chris Allen, Evercore.

CHRIS ALLEN, ANALYST, EVERCORE: Good morning, guys. I just wanted to ask on the information technology segment, just given the upcoming deal with ICE and some of the recent articles in the press about the potential looking at other partners which you guys acknowledge maybe some discussions there. Is it realistic to expect any large signing of agreements in that business until kind of the dust settles on that front, people can figure out who they are going to be dealing with longer-term?

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: Sure. I think it is a really good question, Chris. I think what you are seeing here is an industry that is in transition. Our clients are going from buying products to trying to figure out how to rationalize large chunks of infrastructure. And the technology itself is in transition with more and more emphasis on cloud and virtualized computing and managed services, software as a service, things like that.

So to some extent, some of the hesitation you are seeing is that the things they are demanding are changing and the organizations themselves are trying to figure out the new solution. At the same time, our portfolio of solutions is changing to match that. Transitioning from the more traditional product-based to more of a solutions-based thing.

The backdrop of that, of course, is this ICE deal. So yes, I think that we are certainly going to get those questions and we would expect to get those questions. On the other hand, we are always looking to figure out what is the best combination of our portfolio with partners. That has been our way of doing things anyway, and you have a new management team in there led by Jon Robson that is really thinking about how do they provide the best solution set.

So I would expect that the industry is in transition but that we will start to see, and we are actually seeing, contracts signed. The results kind of hide some of the more traditional products are decreasing, while some of the new products are actually increasing. And we probably have to do a better job with you guys at showing the pipeline and showing that transition so you see how that transition is going, but we are signing new deals. It hasn't ground to a halt. And some of the new deals are actually larger deals and longer deals, and I would expect that that will continue.

CHRIS ALLEN: Thanks, guys.

OPERATOR: Alex Kramm.

ALEX KRAMM, ANALYST, UBS: Good morning. Maybe just to stay on the topic of what Chris just talked about on the technology business, can you maybe try to give a little bit more color on how you would break this business down or how this business breaks down in terms of what are the pieces that are actually really essential to an exchange like market data, how much do they account for?

And then on the other side when you talk to some of your customers, it seems like a lot of the pieces are not very well integrated and they don't really talk to each other as much. So do you actually think that there are some smaller components that are very easy to, I don't know, maybe throw into an auction and see some private equity holders would like to buy more? Do you think this business is actually more of a -- this has to go as a whole or stay together as a whole? Thank you.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: I can help you a little bit. As Larry mentioned, where we have discussed in the past, we restructured this business into three primary -- as the chart shows you -- three primary revenue segments, content, infrastructure, and liquidity and the two largest being content and infrastructure.

So in the content area is the proprietary market data, the data fee handlers, some of the software sales. In the infrastructure we have the connectivity, the safety services and the hosting and the [NYSX] business. In the liquidity we have the co-location services some of the market solutions we are doing for other exchanges and businesses like our (inaudible) operation in Japan.

So it is a pretty diverse segment. Clearly the larger area of growth for this year we are looking at is in content because that is where the market data initiatives are coming in but we have initiatives across hosting is where a lot of these managed services deals come in.

I think Larry was talking a little bit about the co-location and the connectivity that have both news sales and also some lower renewals at times but that is really how we break the business down into those three businesses.

LARRY LEIBOWITZ: Right. I think your observation that says that we haven't integrated some of these offerings is dead on and it is actually consistent with what I was saying about moving from a product based sale to an integrated solutions based sale. Some of that reflects the industry's attitude changing and some of it reflects that we need to do a better job of that and that is exactly what John and his team are working on.

I think speculatively we are going to sell various pieces off to private equity. The honest truth is it is in our competitors' interest to sort of fan those flames so that everybody thinks that these are weak assets. The truth is that most of our competitors are in a reasonable amount of transition themselves in this arena and I think that actually creates a lot of opportunity for natural providers of these solutions like we are because we have the market, we have the connectivity, we have the market data, we have a lot of the pieces that actually naturally sort of go into that and people would like to portray this as a weak position whereas I actually view it as a strong hand.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: I am going to add one more thing to that not to belabor the point. We think we have a pretty good idea of the origin of the leak last week. We actually think it was one of our competitors doing exactly what Larry just said like fanning the flame of uncertainty given the deal that is out there and then coming in behind and saying it is really hard to do something with those guys. I mean they are in a state of flux over there. It is like -- we are not in a state of flux just because a competitor says we are in a state of flux because it suits their marketing pitch.

So I am at a lot of these meetings, Larry is at a lot of these meetings. These are much more complicated discussions than a product sale. A product sale you show someone an a la carte menu they want one item or two. This is a much more comprehensive discussion about sharing infrastructure and things like that. So we are going to remain optimistic and we will remain focused and as we get closer to combining with ICE, we will be able to get the benefit of their input as well.

ALEX KRAMM: That is very helpful. Thank you.

OPERATOR: Niamh Alexander, KBW.

NIAMH ALEXANDER, ANALYST, KEEFE, BRUYETTE & WOODS: Thanks for taking my questions. If I could switch over to the clearing, so you are ahead of the deal -- even you are moving at the end of May as you previously guided. But can you walk me through how to think about the risk of clients, how easy can it be -- should it be for clients? There already is some technology overlap.

And then from the modeling perspective financially, doesn't this accelerate some of the cost savings? Does it accelerate maybe some impairments and some write-downs on some of the investment so far as well?

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: I will try to give you -- it is Duncan -- I will try to give you the outline on sort of what we are doing on the timeline and then Mike can talk a little bit about how that will translate to the results beginning in Q2 and what that means for what we have already spent on what we used to call Project Gemini, etc.

So as I said in my remarks, the project to move the UK derivatives piece from Liffe Clear to ICE Clear is on track to happen at the end of Q2 so it will be the end of June, not the end of May. We will be using May to sort of do member testing. We are collecting all of the Novation certificates now; that is all going very smoothly.

The nice thing about this transition is given that more than 90% of the clients who were connected to Liffe Clear were also connected to ICE Clear, there was very little migration risk. There were only a handful of clients that actually had to do a meaningful technology lift to get this done. The majority of clients were already connected and we are actually relieved that there was less work to do for them than there would have been had we proceeded down the Project Gemini route.

So we are highly confident that will happen by the end of June so we will be clearing at ICE Clear in the second half of the year and then Mike can talk to you about what that means for the kind of results going forward and what we are doing with the expenses that we had already put to work on Gemini last year and before.

MICHAEL GELTZEILER: So the financial benefit of this transaction really twofold. Firstly, when we go live in the beginning of the second half, we will no longer be outsourcing the treasury and risk management with LCH and in turn we will be using ICE Clear and as we have indicated on the call, we will save annualized $30 million from that, $15 million in the second half.

The investment that we made in Gemini in our internal build last year prior to signing the ICE Clear agreement was all written off in the fourth quarter last year so there is nothing else on the balance sheet right now as it relates to that.

Secondarily we have the continental derivatives which we've talked about in the past that we today don't get any revenues or costs and we expect in the first quarter -- end of the first quarter 2014 to realize the revenues on that business and a healthy margin as we also bring that business -- execute that plan.

So two strong financial benefits second half of this year in 2014 coming from clearing.

NIAMH ALEXANDER: Okay, thank you.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: We are going to wrap it there so Stephen, any -- we are going to give you the last word -- anything you want to do to wrap it up?

STEPHEN DAVIDSON: Thanks everyone for joining us and see you later.

DUNCAN NIEDERAUER: As always, the bit team will be available for any one on ones that people need throughout the day. Thanks a lot, everybody. Have a good day.

OPERATOR: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for your participation in today's conference. That concludes the presentation. You may now disconnect. Have a good day.
