In Denmark, it's more about the lending mix, and we have a initiative that we will roll out hopefully towards latter part of this year and that we can probably support the consumer lending business in Denmark to improve that status. And then in Sweden, we've just talked about the mortgage margins here. In the corporate side in Sweden, we are actually seeing lending margins -- signs of that ticking up as well as some potential volume pick up. So that's a positive sign. And I think that gives you hopefully enough flavor.

OPERATOR: We will now take our next question from Adrian Cighi of RBC.

ADRIAN CIGHI, EQUITY ANALYST, RBC CAPITAL MARKETS, LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: I have 2 questions, please. One follow-up on NII, particularly on wholesale funding. How much of a headwind did the U.S. LIBOR higher spread increase contribute to NII this quarter? And assuming it remains at the same level, how much more of headwind will contribute to Q2 and -- I mean, Q3 and Q4. And then on capital, please. You're now meaningfully higher than your own target. While we know that you have a new regulator and -- starting October, do you think they'll ask a much higher management buffer or what is the risk or risks that you see them stopping you from distributing at least some of this excess capital back to shareholder?

CHRISTOPHER REES: So let me start with the capital question. As Casper said, we're very highly capitalized, we've got a huge capital buffer of 230 basis points. And if given the new changes in the Swedish risk weight floors, we're actually one of the highest capitalized banks in Europe. We are currently a Swedish company; and as such, we will go through the normal Swedish SREP process. And as we enter into the SSM, we will go through their process, and we are following those guidelines. So that's really where we're at. We'll have to see what the outcome is of that when we move. And we have -- our intent or we are willing to commit to actually going into the SSM at the current capital levels. The first question was?

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: Funding costs.

CHRISTOPHER REES: Yes, we had a slight higher funding costs than -- in this quarter, which was actually indeed driven mainly by the U.S. And the difference of funding cost was about EUR 5 million, if I recall correctly, and that was driven by that. And I think we are expecting -- and if you look at our funding cost has come down over the last year or so and it's still trending and we still expect a lower, but slightly higher than we have previously guided about the quarter. You got to tell me when we guided. So we still expect funding to be slightly EUR 70 million or so better than the before.

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: Correct. Yes, the change here is that previously we said that the increase in regulatory costs were to be met with lower funding costs, and that's around EUR 100 million on both sides. The regulatory costs are now kicking in EUR 26 million [higher], so that's around EUR 100 million per year. The funding cost, we do expect to be down some EUR 70 million, EUR 80 million. So there is a slightly lower decrease in funding cost than we expected before. Should we take a pause with the telephone conference and enter the room again? So Nicholas, please?

CHRISTOPHER REES: Nicholas's hands is hurting.

NICOLAS MCBEATH, ANALYST, DNB MARKETS, RESEARCH DIVISION: Nicolas McBeath from DNB. A question on the cost guidance that you've kept intact now at EUR 4.9 billion. That was the cost guidance that was set after the Q3 results last year, and if I take into account what's happened with FX movements, we've had quite a depreciation of the Swedish and Norwegian, the kroner versus euro, and also the divestment of Life and Pensions in Denmark, I end up with annualized cost tailwinds of around just slightly north of EUR 100 million. So I understand you'd maybe don't want to change your guidance on the back of such fluctuating factors, but is it fair to assume that assuming the current FX relations that you should be able to outperform the cost target, or has there been kind of other cost headwinds since the cost target was set in Q3 that means that we should still expect cost to be, yes, closer to EUR 4.9 billion?

CHRISTOPHER REES: So first, we'll reiterate the target of EUR 4.9 billion. And on the FX comment, we are -- as Casper said, we are actually changing the firm. We're not -- well, I mean, we're actually do changing the firm in terms of how we leverage the scale and synergies of Nordeaand that drives cost efficiencies as well. So we are not looking at costs and we are not changing our plans on a month-to-month basis depending on the FXs. And hence, the cost target remains at EUR 4.9 billion. And then NordeaLife and Pensions in Denmark.

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: Yes. And as you may remember, we said that this will lower our cost base with some EUR 40 million. And we said before that around EUR 4.9 billion, but that EUR 4.9 billion was slightly above EUR 4.9 billion, and now we are talking about slightly below, but we still round it to EUR 4.9 billion. And then the FX impact in this quarter was EUR 11 million. So that's a tailwind, obviously, as we get. But that -- I mean, we don't forecast on currencies in our cost outlook. So therefore, yes, if we get tailwind, that's good; but we can have headwinds as well. So no one knows.

CHRISTOPHER REES: (technical difficulty) move in 6 months' time in the opposite direction, right?

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: Yes.

NICOLAS MCBEATH: But then revenue should improve as well?

CHRISTOPHER REES: Yes, [it probably has to].

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: Magnus, please.

MAGNUS ANDERSSON: Yes. Just on the wholesale banking to try to be a bit more specific, just a year ago, almost you had invested in London, and you talked about your plans for each business area, and you launched a 12% return target for this business. We are still at [8%], same level as one year ago. Cost/income ratio up quite significantly. You have reduced capital consumption though, withdrawn risk-weighted assets. So when I look at this business, you're not only ones having profitability problems with large corporate business. Do you think this is purely cyclical, or do you think there's something structural? And what do you think about the 12%? Is it really realistic within a 2- to 3-year time period as you see it?

CHRISTOPHER REES: We've talked a lot about the de-risking, and the de-risking actually sits very much in wholesale Russia and with the shipping oil and offshore. And it was also about covering and working with the right client. And I think the initiatives that wholesale have put in place both on the efficiency side and also in terms of shaping the markets business, I do think that they will have momentum and the target still remains at 12%. As indicated, obviously, de-risking -- revenues have risk and we have de-risked something that has higher NII. The efforts now is actually to grow the corporate business that we have had in place. We have deselected a few clients, but we are now seeing a lot of leads, lot of new momentum. So we hope that that will slowly come in 2.5 years' time for sure. And the momentum in the advisory business is good and we have restructured the markets business. So all the components are there to grow and achieve that.

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: Please remember also that the loan losses are still elevated here. In this quarter, we had 1 Danish corporate customer that costed us a quite a lot. So we have 35 basis points, which is elevated.

MAGNUS ANDERSSON: And finally just if I may be a bit bold, do you think you will be able to grow NII at a group level quarter-on-quarter in Q2?

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: We don't do quarterly forecast. Andreas, please, sorry.

ANDREAS HAKANSSON: Just, when I look at the NII in treasury, it declines significantly, and partly or part of that is the transfer pricing that we've seen in other divisions. Can you tell us how much is that and how much is the underlying performance in our treasury? And then you can also say, where does it go, how much goes to the key divisions.

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: I can give you all the details later on, but EUR 40 million is transferred from group functions into the BAs.

ANDREAS HAKANSSON: EUR 40 million?

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: EUR 40 million. And now the remaining EUR 20 million, one is a repayment of a loan. If you may remember, we had a funding agreement with a buyer of Polish business and they have now repaid that fully, and that is around EUR 6 million, EUR 7 million. Then we have slightly higher funding cost as we discussed, and the rest is simply higher regulatory costs, i.e., resolution and DGS.

ANDREAS HAKANSSON: And then could you just...

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: So you can say -- sorry, so you can say this is a fair run rate going forward.

ANDREAS HAKANSSON: And then the IFRS 13, right, in Denmark, how is that split between business banking and retail banking?

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: EUR 77 million in personal banking and EUR 58 million in CBB. Peter?

PETER KESSIAKOFF: Yes. Just a follow-up on NII margins in personal banking. In Finland, NII was down some 10% QonQ. If you just could elaborate a bit on what drove that and...

CHRISTOPHER REES: Yes. We've had a challenge in Finland, that is the front book is having lower margin than the back book. We have had a lot of competition in Finland. However, given the changes recently in the risk or the mortgage floor is actually giving a bit of respite now in terms of the margin. So we do think that this is stabilized and we actually think we can grow market share in Finland from there.

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: And if you look at the decline, I think it's EUR 9 million or so, EUR 8 million, EUR 9 million; and actually EUR 8 million were higher deposit and guarantee fees and EUR 2 million the day count effect. So underlying is not really happening at all.

PETER KESSIAKOFF: Okay. And the commentary on kind of margins and the volume growth in Finland, do you expect an uptick in the margins...

CHRISTOPHER REES: We expect to grow with every market.

PETER KESSIAKOFF: But in terms of margins, is there any particular trend there?

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: On household?

PETER KESSIAKOFF: Yes, I guess, mortgages.

CHRISTOPHER REES: Yes. I think the -- we're seeing a better respite, i.e., a bit of -- with the margin pressures coming off a little bit not necessary that is increasing.

PETER KESSIAKOFF: Okay. Then just one follow-up question on the funding costs. I mean, you mentioned in the past that it would probably be some back-end loaded in the year, that you find in funding cost. How should we look at Q2? I guess, it goes back to Magnus's question on the [quarter 4].

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: That I can support you with. We do expect funding cost to come down with a small amount in Q2, we are talking single-digit euros, and then it will remain on those levels in Q3 and Q4. So fairly small movements from Q1. Do we have more questions from the telephone?

OPERATOR: Certainly. We would take our next question from Bruce Hamilton of Morgan Stanley.

BRUCE HAMILTON, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: Just a follow-up question looking at fees and commissions. When I look at the savings and investment income in Q1, it's down 13% year-over-year, and you've given some reasons. But the assets under management have only declined by 3% over that same period, and it looks like, in terms of where outflows have been, it would probably be where I'd expect, lower rather than higher margins, so institutional. So what's driving the much sharper decline in fee and commission? Is there just structural pressure on fee margins? Is it lower sales, because you're not generating as many sales? How do I understand what's going on there and whether that continues?

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: If you look at asset management fees, I mean, you have seasonality, so you have no performance fees. Then we actually have another seasonal -- Yes. Then we have some seasonality also when it comes to the fund fee days, so we have less in Q1 and the rest is explained by lower volumes. If you look on the income spread under asset management, they have been fairly stable at around 42, 43 basis points. So we don't see any margin pressure.

OPERATOR: We will now take our next question from Riccardo Rovere of Mediobanca.

RICCARDO ROVERE, BANCA DI CREDITO FINANZIARIO S.P.A., RESEARCH DIVISION - RESEARCH ANALYST, MEDIOBANCA: Three questions, if I may. So on the discussions you're having with ECB, when do you think you will be in the position to say something to the market about your capital requirement and risk weighted assets? Do you think this is going to happen ahead of October 2018? This is my first question. The second question I have is on the capital gain that you will get from the sale of UC AB. Is this going to be treated like normal earning, so it's going to be part of a potential dividend payment? The third question I have is on the risk-weighted assets. That's come down a bit this quarter. Assuming the loan book doesn't change, should we expect IRB parameters to continue to improve over the next few quarters, and so RWA eventually to go -- to keep going down if the loan book remains flat or to go up less than the loan book, should the loan book start growing again? And the very final question I have is on -- given that the share price is kind of over and over, closer and closer to the tangible equity, would you consider efficient to maybe replace or substitute part of the dividend payment with a buyback?

CHRISTOPHER REES: So let me maybe start with the capital and then see if I remember the following questions. So as I said earlier, we are in -- under the Swedish regulation, we are following the Swedish SREP process for 2018. We will then -- and we continue having dialog with ECB as we go forward. When we go into the SSM, we will follow their process. So the capital outcome of that will come out when we have clarity from SSM, how we land in terms of our discussions in accordance to their processes. And that also relates to question on buybacks. Buybacks, first of all, will need to be decided by the AGM at a later stage, and we will see what the capital outcome is as and when we are in SSM and what happens in the future.

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: And on the capital gain, and I'm looking at Powell, I think it's other operating income, yes. And it's net of tax. And that we plan to report in Q2. We also plan to have the capital gain from the NordeaLife and Pensions Denmark in Q2, and that number is around EUR 250 million.

CHRISTOPHER REES: Did we miss a question?

RICCARDO ROVERE: Alright. No, no, no. I think I'm -- just on risk-weighted assets.

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: Exactly, yes. And decline in this quarter, we had EUR 3.1 billion decline. Of that, almost everything relates to improved credit quality, it's around EUR 2.5 billion and the rest is FX; and the FX is then...

RICCARDO ROVERE: I understand that. But do you think it's going to go on like that? I mean, the credit quality within the group would allow further positive migrations, I don't know how to call it.

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: We don't give guidance on that. We are very happy when it happens.

OPERATOR: We will now take our next question from Kim Bergoe of Deutsche Bank.

KIM BERGOE, RESEARCH ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK AG, RESEARCH DIVISION: Actually most of my questions have been answered, but again just a little bit on what you said. Casper, I think you briefly just used the wording being over-capitalized, but obviously as you're saying, your cash spend is now going down, you've got these one-off effects coming in in the coming quarters. So it looks like your cash generation is going to be relatively strong this year as well. How should we be thinking about this? I mean, that you -- your buffer, what does that mean, what do we -- what should we expect from that? Is that just -- if it's not really -- if it's not distributable, then is it a buffer? So just how should we be thinking about this?

CHRISTOPHER REES: Maybe I'll just comment very briefly on the dividend policy. Obviously, we keep a dividend policy as is and we are accruing EUR 0.06 to EUR 0.09 for this quarter, which is nothing more than EUR 0.01 more than the previous one, and that is in line with our dividend policy. We have actually communicated that policy to our new regulators and we had no pushback on that. So that remains intact. And I think the answer to your other question remains as is, i.e., we will follow the process in SSM and we'll see the outcome of that and we will communicate that in due course.

OPERATOR: (Operator Instructions) We will now take our next question from Jacob Kruse of Autonomous.

JACOB MAX KRUSE, PARTNER, SCANDINAVIAN BANKS, AUTONOMOUS RESEARCH LLP: Can I just ask, when I look at the league table data you provided for your large corporate banking business and your commentary around some of those deals perhaps being more Q2. If I understand you correctly, this -- how much of your Q1 deal flows was reflected in Q1 and how much do you feel is flowing into Q2, or -- not precise numbers but what kind of magnitude are you talking about there? And then my other question was just quickly, the headquarter move that is scheduled for October 1, '18, is that on track and is that still where you expect to have that finalized?

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: On the first question, was that how basically the level of income in Q2 in the wholesale banking, is that what you were asking?

JACOB MAX KRUSE: Well, no. I guess, what I'm asking is, if Q1 -- if you're saying Q1 was a strong quarter in the wholesale bank from a league table point of view, but perhaps not as strong from the revenue point of view, is that element of Q1 performance getting about to be booked in Q2?

CHRISTOPHER REES: I mean, we've had a -- I mean the league tables are strong, the environment was good, and we've had very good deals in Q1 as well. But it's -- it was weak, but the momentum now going into Q2 is strong. So there is an element of pipeline that we have, which is -- that we see which is good, that we hope will materialize in Q2.

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: And also if you look at the tombstones we presented under the investment banking chart, you saw some very sizable deals that are not closed yet. And unfortunately, we are not allowed to invoice before we close the deal, but we plan to do that in Q2.

JACOB MAX KRUSE: Right. Okay. And this headquarter move?

CHRISTOPHER REES: Yes. At the moment, we are continuing our discussions with the relevant authorities and we are aiming and on track to meet the 1st of October date.

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: And maybe [already into] with the head of the Swedish FSA and we were happy to hear that he has exactly the same view as we have on the capital side. So we are pleased to see that we are aligned in the thinking. So do we have any further questions from the telephone?

OPERATOR: There are no further questions on the telephone at this time.

RODNEY ALFVÃ©N: Okay. Thank you very much. Thank you very much for coming to this event. You're, of course, always free to call me or Powell at your discretion. We will be in London tomorrow as we have an analyst breakfast, but all of you are welcome. Thank you very much.

CHRISTOPHER REES: Thank you very much.

Corporate Participants

Natixis S.A., Research Division - Head of Banks Sector Research & Analyst

RBC Capital Markets, LLC, Research Division - Analyst

* Karl Jonathan Peace

Crédit Suisse AG, Research Division - MD

* Kirishanthan Vijayarajah

HSBC, Research Division - Analyst

* Lorraine Quoirez

UBS Investment Bank, Research Division - Director and Equity Analyst

* Maxence Patrick Patrick Laurent Le Gouvello du Timat

Jefferies LLC, Research Division - Equity Analyst

* Nick Davey

Redburn (Europe) Limited, Research Division - Research Analyst

* Omar Fall

* Pierre Chedeville

CM-CIC Market Solutions, Research Division - Analyst

* Stefan M. Stalmann

Autonomous Research LLP - Partner, Swiss and French Banks

BofAMerrill Lynch, Research Division - Equity Analyst

Presentation

OPERATOR: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the Société Générale conference call. Frédéric Oudéa, Chief Executive Officer; and Philippe Heim, Chief Financial Officer, will present the group first quarter 2018 results. Gentlemen, please go ahead.

FRéDéRIC OUDéA, CEO & DIRECTOR, SOCIéTé GéNéRALE SOCIéTé ANONYME: Good morning to all of you. Thanks for attending our conference call on the first quarter results. I suggest that we proceed like usually. We'll meet with Philippe Helm, our CFO, with short presentation, and then we will, with our management team, answer your questions. I'd like to again highlight the good discipline that we keep usually, 2 questions per each person.

So let me start immediately with the first slide, Page 4, to have an overview of our first quarter results. In an environment, which was robust in terms of economic activity, mainly across the world and in particular in the Eurozone. And with market environment where we commenced with a sharp contrast from one region to the other. When we look at this first quarter, first of all, if you look at the profitability on an underlining basis, normalizing for the IFRIC 21, a return on tangible equity of 10.9%. We have still work to do but I find this figure encouraging.

When we look at the net banking income, first of all, good developments for all our retail activity . In French retail, good commercial momentum, with revenues still affected by the low interest rate environment and also by the effect of the larger renegotiations on the mortgage, which creates to a certain extent an unfavorable base effect. Fundamentally, we are advancing in line with our expectations toward the stabilization of revenue, we expect for the full year of 2018.

Regarding International Retail Banking & Financial Services, we have positive momentum across the board. We will look at this more in detail. And regarding the Global Banking & Investor Solutions, of course, we suffer from the decrease of the dollar versus the euro. We have roughly on these activities, 40% of our revenues, which are influenced by the euro-dollar foreign exchange rate. And also, as I said, by a sharp contrast that we've seen between our different activities and geographies.

In a very awkward quarter, which was already commented by all the banks, we have a strong start, but then something more sluggish in February and March. We feel in particular, very strong activity on the slow equity business in the U.S., while on the other hand, in Europe, we had -- we saw low demand, for example, on structured products with probably some impact related to MiFID. All in all solid performance with the decrease of revenues, but of course, which is influenced by the business model in the capital market activities.

We maintained a strong discipline on the cost, of course, the cost base, for example, retail has an all -- let me just remind you that all our transformation costs are allocated to the businesses, then and you will notice, in particular, the first quarter that we have a Corporate Centre, which is at the breakeven. So we have all our costs of transformation on the businesses. But beyond this, we maintained a strong discipline on the cost. Can I just highlight the increase of the contribution to the Single Resolution Fund. This first quarter, we, of course -- the IFRIC 21 effect, we have booked EUR 430 million, that's net of tax, it's unpredictable, which represent an increase of EUR 78 million compared with last year, and again, of course, allocated to the business.

Regarding the cost of risk, it remains very low at around 18 basis points. Let me just remind you that it was a similar figure for 2017 at 19 basis points. Again underlying net income, at EUR 1.2 billion. And I've as mentioned already, this return on tangible equity at 10.9% again normalizing the impact of IFRIC 21.

Regarding just the Slide 5, the objective on the 3 main businesses. As you know, for this year, it's a very important year of transformation. We want to progress and in particular the utilization of our processes. We effectively guarantee closing back offices. We are reducing the number of branches and at the same time, deploy the new growth initiatives. I like to highlight that we will look at that more in detail in particular. The strong dynamic of Boursorama with more than 126,000 new clients during just the first quarter. And I already commented on our expectation of a stabilization of revenues in 2018.

Regarding all our International Retail Banking & Financial Services, we are posting, as I said, strong revenue for growth, in particular, on the International Retail Banking and the Insurance business, we talked about an 8% revenue growth on the like-for-like basis, and with good differences across the board. The return on normative equity, the underlying return on normative equity stands at 17%. We are basically at our target for 2020 and above. Fundamentally, we want to pursue and we are confident that we would see the kind of -- this kind of perspective for 2018.

In Global Banking & Investor Solutions, what we are seeing is again the impact and the effect of this transition towards a more normalized monetary policy. Europe is behind the U.S. It's very clear, as I said. We saw all the elements of the markets in U.S., perspective of higher rates, the positive impact of lower tax cuts, which means a better result for the U.S. tax but also potentially share buybacks. The volatility effect, in particular, impacting big tax stocks. The VIX impact on certain products, we had not the same thing in Europe, and we have, again, in mind the progressive normalization but we -- it would -- it might take some time.

Overall, what we want to achieve is a focus on our 2 main strategic objectives in terms of European product, and I'd like to highlight our #1 position, for example, in terms of the euro-denominated bond for corporates as well as I must say a #1 position, for example, for global securitization. So we see the benefits of a strong positioning.

In capital market, we will see that in more detail, and let me highlight, we had confirmation of market share gain in 2017. And you will see the more precise figures, that stronghold of product. What we want to achieve is, again, to pursue the development also of our derivative franchise on a worldwide basis. With a selective and a strong optimization of capital usage. When you look at our GBIS results this quarter, we post more than 10% return on normative equity after-tax that shows this discipline, and we want to achieve globally this capacity to outperform our European peers in terms of profitability.

Now I will pass to Philippe, who will enter more into the details.

PHILIPPE HEIM, DEPUTY CEO, SOCIéTé GéNéRALE SOCIéTé ANONYME: Thank you very much, Frédéric. So now let's have a look on all the aspects of the group results, starting with the cost of risk. If you move to Slide 6, you have the description of what we've got in terms of cost of risk.

First, the group results, we see that we have a very low cost of risk in Q1, coming at 18 basis points versus 24 last year. It reflects, of course, the [once again] the structural results we delivered in the past 3 years. It reflects the so -- the buy-ins and trade economic environment. You can note also that in terms of nonperforming loans, although we've (inaudible) we move down from 4.8% to 4.2%. And then all across the board, in every business line, we had the same pattern. So cost of risk at 29 in Q1, 28 in international retail, and net, let's say, reversal of a positive cost of risk in GBIS, minus 5 basis points.

So what is the outlook now going forward, I may -- they anticipate a questions. We are indicating during Investor Day that it's reasonable from this point to anticipate the gradual normalization of cost of risk during the cycle and converging positively to something between 35 and 40 basis points in 2020. Our guidance for this year was for cost of risk between 25 and 30 basis points. Obviously, given the low level we see in Q1, this guidance can be qualified as very conservative.

On capital, I will be short, not surprised at all on capital. You have the CET1 ratio standing at 11.2%, down by 20 basis points. But related to 2 elements I mentioned before during the year-end results, you have the first-time application impact of IFRS 9, and we decided not to adopt this, let's say the phase-in approach, so to take in one go the impact of IFRS 9. As all French banks, we have this methodological add-on on irrevocable commitments on Single Resolution Fund with impact of 8 basis points. On the top of that, we have the usual seasonal effect of IFRIC 21. So bottom line, if the CET1 ratio is down by 20 basis points, it will neutralize the effect I mentioned before. We created this quarter, 7 basis points of capital. So on a yearly basis, something between 25 and 30 basis points. So let's say, right in the middle of our usual guidance in terms of capitalization. I confirm that we expect a CET1 ratio at [11.5%] at the end of this year.

Regarding the other metric of the balance sheet, you see that with the benefit of the issuance of the AT1 issuance beginning at April, with a TC capital about 17.1%, leverage ratio at 4.2%. We are already TLAC compliant. So overall, we have a very solid balance sheet structure, and we very recently from end of guide from Moody's, our senior debt rating has been lifted from A2 to A1.

Page 8. I will be brief, this is the summary of the consolidated results, with the elements already described. So revenues down by 2.5%, affected by a change effect. Operating expenses, if we -- linearize or annualize the IFRIC 21 effects, operating expenses were up by 1%. Net cost of risk is very low at EUR 208 million, so we have reported group net income at EUR 850 million. But we're smoothing out the effect of IFRIC 21. We cannot [waive] our underlying group net income at EUR 1.2 billion, representing a ROTE of 10.9%.

So now let's review the activity of, let's say, the businesses particular with the French Retail. And we'll focus first on individual customer segments, where we continue to deploy our model. Regarding Société Générale and Crédit du Nord, as a foreword, I think that in Q1, we have maintained our strong discipline on the quality of our origination, both in terms of margin levels and risk appetite, and focusing on mass affluent and wealthy clients. Boursorama, and then we'll elaborate on this, demonstrates the strength of its customer acquisition engine. And regarding specifically, to let's say, the client base, the number of mass affluent and wealthy clients was up by 5% in Q1.

Regarding the commercial activity, we are first on the real estate market. Our production was down by 19% but it was the high base points, Q1 of last year. Issue analyzed sequentially, the production is up 4.7% compared to this Q4. We were on last year in the middle of a negotiation wave. This movement is now over. The current annual negotiation base stands at 3% in the Q1 versus 26% last year. In consumer credit space, the production dropped 18%, the outstanding is up by 2.4%. It's interesting I think to mention that we have also consumer credit activity in France namely in auto loans, in [CGI book] in Western Europe. If you put together all our consumer credit outstanding books, in fact we have an increase of 7%.

Regarding the key initiative this quarter, you can see that is net inflows of private banking activity is well oriented, an increase also EUR 1.1 billion. Again in Boursorama, record quarter in terms of acquisition is more than 126,000 new clients, close to 1.4 million clients. And I have to highlight that Boursorama, contrary to strong market players who only develop payment services, Boursorama is a full-fledged bank delivering a compounded set of products and services.

Switching to professional and corporate clients on Page 11, you see that we continue to develop [supply and debt] with a goal of 2.5% for the corporate clients. The book is up by 3.3%. We decided this quarter to make a specific focus on Credit du Nord's model. You know that 60% of Credit du Nord's customers and professionals are SMEs, with a very high level of customer satisfaction that is a clear differentiating element. We have a network of professional banks capable of addressing specific local characteristics and needs of our clients. And this model is powerful in terms of acquisition in Q1 alone, where the 6,200 new relationships.

A word on transformation. We describe largely, let's say, the strategy, we deploy on the French market. The idea is to completely reshuffle overall the distribution platform and your guiding model by 2020, with the reduction of number (inaudible) by 20%. This will be, of course, a company that by roughly 3,400 redundancy. This confirmation program, of course, requires investment and expenditures. The HR aspects are covered by the exceptional provision we took in Q4, roughly EUR 400 million. As you may know, in early March, Société Générale, we designed -- we leveraged on the new scheme introduced by the Macron ordinance (inaudible) French labor code. In this context, we have signed a maturity agreement with the trade unions for corrective mutually agreed combination, what you call (foreign language) of more than 2,000 positions. And we're one of the first corporates using this scheme. Over and above each aspect, there are other operating expenses, other investments cover regarding the depletion of the network coverage. We plan to close one of our branches this year. Where we saw expenses or investment to overall and upgrade the customer experience and positive in that respect. We have a [land-locked delivery] this year with innovative tools like biometric face recognition of 360 view to have a real-time [intrinsic] vision of all premium data. At the end of 2018, this is an important milestone, 50% of our main processes will have been digitalized within the Société Générale network.

So what is the magnitude of this investment? What is important to keep in mind is that this is fully consistent with our trajectory. So between 2016 and 2020. As indicated during our Investor Day, the cost increase will be -- the annual cost increase will be contained within 1%. And more specifically regarding 2018, costs are expected to increase by less than [3%].

So moving to Slide 13, to give you an overview of the results for the French Retail division. Revenues are down by 1.6%. So we confirm that, positively we are heading towards a stabilization expected for the full year. It should be positive because indeed, if we take the example of the interest margin revenues, they are down by 4.3%. We have the usual, let's say, effect of interest rate (inaudible) has on the reinvestment of deposits. But on top of that, the bulk of, let's say, this decrease is related to the renegotiation wave of last year. During which, we received fees and revenues associated with renegotiation and early termination of around EUR 27 million. This effect will be fully absorbed between Q2 and Q3. That's why its normalization and the full year stabilization will be seen moderately in the year.

Regarding commissions, they are slightly down by 0.9% due to, for example, the disposal of OnVista in Germany, the subsidiary of Boursorama, where we saw bits and pieces of this gradual business effect. Bottom line, it is a good start of the year (inaudible) and private banking.

Operating expenses increased by 4.2%. Net cost of risk is relatively stable compared with last year. All those elements leading to a contribution to the operating income of EUR 270 million.

So now let's move to IBFS, starting with Europe, Russia and Africa, delivering altogether a return on normative equity of 15.5%. We continue to enjoy in Europe very strong results in a sound economic environment with solid growth of outstanding loans, up by 8%, ranging between 12% in Western Europe in consumer finance space to 5% in Czech Republic in a lot of mature markets, but still a good performance given the characteristic of the market. In this context, revenues were up 6%. We have a clear positive jaws and profitability stands at 21% for Europe.

Regarding Russia, of course, the situation I described is one of the -- quarter's starting just in Jan and ending end of March. In the context of progressive normalization, an inflation of 2.5 is stable at that time, ruble. Interest rates growth down to 7.25% by Central Bank of Russia. We have the usual seasonality effect in Q1 and the continuity of the background we have identified the past 2 quarters. So progressively, a catch up in the accelerated pace with recovery of retail loan as the production is up by 29%. Overall, revenues are up by 9% in Russia.

In Africa, the economic environment is very solid between the Mediterranean Basin and Sub-Saharan Africa. We have the loan book up by 19%, revenues up by 13%. The point for us in Africa is to lift the return on normative equity of above 15% by both developing our revenues and increasing -- improving our operating efficiency, we will accelerate deployment of regional ops where support functions and (inaudible) will be located and put.

A word on the bankinsurance model, Page 15. An activity which we guided EUR 2.1 billion of revenues in 2017, up by 8%. This will -- those revenues are distributed between the insurance business unit collecting EUR 0.8 million of revenues and the retail network for EUR 1.3 billion through distribution fees. We want, down the road, to further increase the concentration of insurance activities through lifting the equipment rate of our retail banking clients, for example, our objective the in P&C space. We want to lift the P&C equipment rate from 9% in 2017 to 12% in 2020. And also we want to increase the share of unit-linked products in life insurance outbound. And one of the key factors of success, of course, we need to deploy to improve the simplicity and liquidity of the customer experience. That's the (inaudible) we have already implemented several innovations. For example, (inaudible) with electronic signature to subscribe in a fully car autonomous manner, car insurance or property insurance.

Page 16, you have the big picture on IBFS. So revenues, up by 3.9% adjusted for changes in cost structure and at constant exchange rates. Operating expenses rose at the same time by 3.2% because we need to accompany the movement of development. Overall, IBFS delivered high level of contribution, EUR 429 million, stable with last year. And this is a quite nice performance given the fact that we now consolidate only 80% of ALD following the (inaudible). And you remember that we had benefited last year after the sale of KomercnÃ­ banka head office for prospects effect of EUR 17 million. And I think that before commenting the year-on-year evolution on specific statements, but online it's very relevant and it's (inaudible) to see that over particular time between 2018 and 2017 all across, let's say, the activity on geographies, we are one of the banks capable of increasing market share. So relatively speaking we move from 3.5% to 3.7%. We strengthened our market share in equity, in FIC and commodity.

So now moving to, let's say, the result of [GB], starting with global markets and investor services. Revenues were down by 13%, with diverging developments between businesses and regions. Starting first with fixed income, activities declined significantly by 27%, mentioning that Q1 structure was (inaudible) for activity from extremely lower activity in Europe, in particular. Financing, which was (inaudible) last year, was weakened by increased competition. On the other hand, we have a pretty resilient performance of the structured product with FICC underlying [into 1]. Regarding equity, revenues were down by 5% if we neutralize the foreign exchange effect (inaudible) 2 factors. We have a pretty good performance, onshore products and specifically in the U.S., but we are less exposed on the U.S. activity and geography. Regarding structured products, which are represent our franchise, we have less, let's say, buoyant environment, in particular, in Europe with a more pronounced weight (inaudible) by our clients and, at some point, more conservative buyers -- of course, the volatility spiked in February. Moving to securities services, very good quarter, revenues up by 9% with a good level of commissions.

Moving to Slide 19, Financing & Advisory. 50% of revenues in this division are in USD. So if we neutralize this effect, let's say, this is -- and we neutralize the foreign exchange impact, revenues were roughly stable, minus 1%, with good performance in all asset-based activity, export financing, real estate, project finance. Revenues in securitization were up for the ninth consecutive quarter. We have also quite nice achievements in this year. Finally, in wealth and asset management, revenues were down by minus 2% [versus] last quarter. We had good, let's say, momentum in terms of inflows, more than EUR 7 billion. Altogether, Lyxor and one wealth management, we reached an all-time high of EUR 234 billion of AUM.

So the summary of the results for GBIS, revenues down by 13% due to negative foreign exchange effect. OpEx were up by 1%, impacted significantly by the increase of the contribution to the Single Resolution Fund (inaudible). Cost of risk remained very low. And the contribution of GBIS to group net income stood at EUR 166 million. And excluding -- let's say, excluding the effect of IFRIC 21, we stick to a cost stability at 10.2% for GBIS.

A word on the Corporate Centre, Slide 21. I would like to remind you that with the new IFRS 9 standard, we have, let's say, the effect of revaluation of our own financial liabilities and will now go directly to the shareholder equity. We have, this quarter, a positive GOI, plus EUR 36 million. Regarding our guidance of Corporate Centre, GOI of minus EUR 400 million, we can state that this guidance is conservative. And we will come back to you regarding, let's say, the guidance later on this year. Lastly, regarding disputes, we can confirm that we have entered into a phase of [marquee] discussions with relevant authorities to conclude the production agreement on labor and (inaudible) cases within the next few weeks. We have good visibility regarding the financial impact. We are comfortable with the around EUR 1 billion provision. We're satisfied within our provision of EUR 2.3 billion.

So much from me. I'll leave the floor to Frédéric for the conclusion.

FRéDéRIC OUDéA: Thank you, Philippe. Just in a few words, Slide 23, to recap our main objective for 2018. I think we have already commented on the revenues. I'd like again to highlight that this year will be a very significant year of transformation, in particular, in the French retail but not -- just on the French retail. I'd like to again reemphasize on our commitment to deliver on cost and maintain a strong discipline. The outlook for the cost of risk, as we've already mentioned, is good, and our current guidance appears to be conservative, very conservative.

On the refocusing that we had announced, I can say that the processes are underway to deliver our target and we can expect some material announcements by year-end. And of course, at the same time, we are fully committed to objectives in terms of responsibility, CSR, for example, in terms of climate change, and the deployment of our culture and conduct program.

Can I just, of course, finish also by saying a few words on the change of our management team that we have announced also yesterday? As you know, the board had to face the unexpected departure of Didier Valet, who was, in practice, our younger Deputy CEO in a team of 3 Deputy CEOs with myself plus the CEO. So having to deal with the situation, the board organized a very structured process with a very clear time frame with 2 objectives: first of all, of course, ensure full continuity and capacity to deliver our strategic plan; and at the same time, preparing the future, the succession plan. The process was -- and we generally use that process to explore all the internal options and, of course, review the potential external options with these 2 objectives in mind. In practice, between the different internal options, we decided to go for the most ambitious one. We could have -- both could have made the choice just to replace Didier and then implement progressive changes alongside the strategic plan. The board decided to go for something more ambitious, on one hand, ensuring continuity and, in particular, announcing a little bit ahead of the usual framework that -- they will effectively propose the renewal of my mandate as CEO to the vote of our shareholders in the general assembly of 2019; and at the same time, change effectively the composition, in particular, and more marginally the organization, going for 4 Deputy CEOs instead of 3.

First of all, let me say in that context, Bernardo Sanchez decided to leave the group to pursue other opportunity. As you know, Bernardo has been with us 8 years, has very good -- great contribution with the strong current improvements of the results in IBFS that's reflected also in the first quarter as well as in 2017 and has launched successfully this long-term transformation of the French Retail. And I would like to thank him and really highlight his contribution to our group.

We have decided to appoint, alongside Séverin, who was already Deputy CEO, 3 new Deputy CEOs, which I think share the same -- I mean, they are all very seasoned, experienced bankers with different backgrounds. Let me just remind you that Philippe Aymerich is appointed the Deputy CEO in charge of all the French Retail activities and the financial services. What I mean by this is IT, procurement and real estate. And he has spent 30 years with Societe Generalemainly in corporate investment banking activities in the risk function. He had been the CEO of the U.S. -- Deputy CEO of the risk function and was before the CEO of Crédit du Nord. Philippe Heim, our current CFO, joined us in 2007 and after and experienced as a senior banker, head of strategy and CFO, is taking over as the Deputy CEO in charge of international retail banking activities and financial services as well as the insurance. Séverin, who, as you know, is also -- has a diverse profile in the [financial] industry and joined us more than 10 years ago. He is taking over Didier Valet's role, something that he -- activities that he supervised in the past. And we will -- again, the objective to implement the strategy and further nurture our talents. And Diony Lebot -- and I say I'm very proud to appoint the first woman as the Deputy CEO in Societe Generale, is also a seasoned banker, Greek by background. She spent more than 30 years with us mainly on the businesses in the wholesale banking business. She worked, for example, as head of the U.S. activities in 2012. She has had also responsibilities in the structured financing business as well as in the coverage business of wholesale claims and was, since 2015, head of our risk department.

Alongside these appointments, I'm very happy also to have been able to appoint additional strong talents of Societe Generale. William Kadouch is taking over as CFO. William, the same thing, joined us in 2007. He has had an experience as senior banker in U.S. banks then was also a senior banker with us and followed the same path (inaudible) Philippe, after his senior banker experience, was appointed head of strategy and now CFO. You can see that we are building career development with a very long-term plan to [feed] our succession planning objectives. And Sylvie Rémond is taking over Diony Lebot as head of risk; same thing, has long experience as a banker with Societe Generalemainly in the structured finance business. She had been our also deputy head of risk, and she was currently co-head of our coverage activity.

So if you wish, what I'd like to highlight in looking at this profile, there are backgrounds -- there are ages. I must say I'm very proud to have the team of very seasoned bankers who know how to work together, who had been fully committed in the preparation of the strategic plan, who are diversified. And we have a real force, the diversity of the team, and I must say I think we are actually delivering on the 2 objectives, continuity and capacity to deliver the strategic plan and prepare the future.

So that's what I wanted to say, and we are now open to your questions.

Questions and Answers

FRéDéRIC OUDéA: Tarik, I will take the first question and leave the floor to Philippe for the second one. First of all, again, I'd like to come back to Slide 17, and here, we are presenting figures provided to us by Coalition. And on the slide, you can see that we have gained, marginally every year, market share. It is in terms of revenues. And that's true for all geographies, and that's true for all products. Now if I jump to the first quarter, as I said, now we saw very contrasted activities. And just to reflect that, we have very good activities, for example, on the equity flow in the U.S. while, on the other hand, it was more muted on the credit flow in the U.S. And in Europe, we have effectively low demand on structured product at the beginning of this year as well as on the [flow side]. But based on the Coalition figures, which enable us, if I would say, to model, for example, an average U.S. bank in terms of business mix and that's, for example, for equity, so of course, much more geared towards U.S. equity, cash and derivatives through a business than we are. And we have plugged towards that model our own performances for each segment in the beginning of this year. And effectively, in practice, we end up with increases of revenues in equity. I would say [periods] because it increases, which are pretty similar to the ones posted by our [best] competitors. So we have really the feeling that we have, this quarter, something very contrasted. And we feel that explains largely the document of peers as well as reflected in our own performances, for example, on the U.S. flow and, of course, with a percentage of our business which is smaller. Looking forward, we think that we have effectively centered our strategy on the businesses which offer, in the longer term, the best growth revenue prospectives. At the same time, we also had factored in our strategic plan that we would -- could still see in the coming quarters this awkward transitional environment in Europe in particular, where effectively, rates will increase progressively. Volatility might not come back structurally and that clarity would be probably needed in Europe to have more stable conditions. We have in mind to further develop this activity and, of course, take advantage of further synergies with our client base. There is more capacity to optimize the franchise on that business. So I think that again, this quarter is very contrasted. These conditions might last for -- again, for sure, for a few months. But going forward, if I look at the next 3 years, we are again considering (inaudible) capacity to deliver growth in these activities. And there was, again, nothing specific beyond conservative. And we maintain a conservative risk approach when we hedge our book of equity structured products. It can cost in the kind of environment we've seen. But there was, in our view, nothing specific beyond these contrasted -- more than ever contrasted activity levels depending on geographies and products. Can I turn back to Philippe regarding the costs?

PHILIPPE HEIM: Yes, Tarik, okay. So regarding the cost, you have a different way of considering the cost. So the reported view -- so we have an increase of 4.7% at face value. But this is, of course, inflated by the IFRIC 21 effect and notably the surge of the contribution to the Single Resolution Fund. Yes, the cost of risk should increase a little bit compared still with write-back, what we have in mind for risk appetite overall, and it should not change the picture. And on the Corporate Centre, we've been discussing for quite a while -- some time the division of the Corporate Centre. I'd like to highlight that we have finished the journey to charge the liquidity cost to the businesses. We don't allocate the restructuring costs (inaudible) it should be more negative than what we are preparing in this quarter -- presenting but (inaudible) we've also commented on gross operating income which -- just to be pretty conservative this year. So we are again confident that in a different environment, progressively, normalization of rate, we will effectively achieve this target with the benefit of the (inaudible), I would like to highlight, of our effectively (inaudible) of capital. And just to finish, I'd like to say 10.9% return of intangible equity for this quarter, precisely without exceptional performances on the market, seems to me to be an encouraging performance.

OPERATOR: Next question from Mr. Bruce Hamilton from Morgan Stanley.

BRUCE ALLAN HAMILTON, EQUITY ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY, RESEARCH DIVISION: So I'm going to go back to CIB. Or was there any hedging imperfection that drove some unexpected moves in Q1 that might reverse because clearly that would help on the book forward? And then linked to that, I mean, in what is normally the best quarter of the year, you've printed just over EUR 50 million of pre-provision profit, down 85% year-over-year in the global markets business. Cost are flat, revenue are down 17%. So it doesn't look like you can hold off taking more aggressive action on costs for long. So how quickly and how dynamically can you move the cost base there to improve your returns because it looks like you're quite -- I realize some of this will build into the longer-term plan, but if it was far off kilter, you need to do something far off. So how are you thinking about that?

PHILIPPE HEIM: I will maybe let Frank way ahead of us (inaudible) the global capital markets, it's a little bit your -- the first element of your question, which is related to structured products. And on the cost, we have, in this division also a capacity to optimize the structure of the cost. And when I say this, it can be by reallocating resources from one sub activity to another, which will effectively at least improve the profitability on capital. Second, as I said, and there are some structural further action with IT investments, which will lead effectively to further cuts, for example, in support functions, and we have planned which are ambitious on that front, we're also further off-shoring. So it cannot be -- it will take a few quarters, it's not something that you change from one quarter to the other, but we have plan as well. We have presented that actually GBIS will contribute to the asset on the productivity in the 3-year strategy by, if I remember, something like EUR 300 million, I think, under the control of Philippe Helm, but I have in mind that kind of objective.

PHILIPPE HEIM: Frank, can you perhaps elaborate a little bit on the first elements of Bruce's questions?

FRANK BENZIMRA, HEAD OF ASIA EQUITY STRATEGY, SOCIETE GENERALECROSS ASSET RESEARCH: Yes, it's sure that our activity on structured product, we have -- a strong part of our revenue is coming from distribution of structured product to the retail. It's true in Asia and it's true as well in Europe. And compared with the -- to the competition, we are more geared toward the distribution products and especially on the equity side. And it's true that in Q1, while we are seeing a strong development objectivity in Asia, it was quiet in Europe. So we think that there was the MiFID II impact. And also the fact that maybe compared to Asia and the U.S., there was less story in the equity market in the Q1 in Europe, which explains as well why we are seeing a relatively quiet activity on the distribution product in Europe.

OPERATOR: Next question from Maxence Le Gouvello from Jefferies.

MAXENCE PATRICK PATRICK LAURENT LE GOUVELLO DU TIMAT, EQUITY ANALYST, JEFFERIES LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: I would have 2 questions. The first one is for Frederic. The stock is down by 6% to 7% today. FRéDéRIC OUDéA: First of all, I will leave the second part of your question to Philippe, Maxence. I noticed that we are down by 5% because the European banks, which are also, I noticed, down today. And I will not mean that you can see that some of the result disappointed after performance which was not so bad since the beginning of the year. Structurally, we don't look at our performance on a daily basis, but we have, yes, due to 2 things: first, definitely the base of the crisis, may I say, which means put behind the litigations, we have commented on that front. You might have noticed our communication, which is to say that regarding 2 of the 3 potential settlements we have on LIBOR and LIA, we are having very active discussions, and we think we can potentially settle in the coming days or weeks. And effectively, we've anticipated potential financial impact in line with the level of provisioning that we have previously communicated around EUR 1 billion within our general EUR 2.3 billion provision. That's one. And then effectively, structurally, sure in the market that we can deliver once again the level of profitability and effectively then have valuation much more in line with I would say between the tangible book and the book. We are just at the beginning of these profits. We are just starting with 2018. As I've said, we're probably are mixed in terms of the results, which does not reflect market expectation at the beginning of this year. But we, as I've said, have a 10.9% return on tangible equity, which I think is encouraging, just at the beginning of this journey, knowing that when I think I can see improvements on the revenue and the cost and the cost efficiency going forward. And as I've said, I don't expect a very significant deterioration of the cost of risk. So it is just the beginning of the journey. We've always felt that, yes, we have to deliver consistently our results, so it could take a few quarters. But I think fundamentally, the development we are seeing in our businesses are in line with our anticipations, of course, in a stable environment, which is more contrasted in Europe than in the U.S. Philippe, can you elaborate?

PHILIPPE HEIM: Yes, of course. So the increase of cost we've seen in the French Retail this quarter is around plus 4.2%. Of course, we have to smooth the effect of IFRIC 21. We have to search for a neutralized perimeter effect. So increase are discussed is around this 3.2%. To simplify, this is the debate, I assume that apart from what we can call the natural [drift] of expenses, roughly around 1%. Everything is more or less ready for transformation. So to give you, it's in order of [92] So say what we invest, what we didn't take to the transformation that says large-scale transformation of the network both on the distribution channels and on your accounting model.

OPERATOR: Next question from Delphine Lee from JPMorgan.

DELPHINE LEE, ANALYST, JP MORGAN CHASE & CO, RESEARCH DIVISION: So 2 on my side. First of all, I just wanted to come back on your guidance for French retail costs on Slide 12. Just to understand, the 3% -- on the 3%, because it looks like the consensus is expecting cost flattish. So I'm just wondering where that's coming from? And the except for no charges, I assume is only the EUR 400 million, which you booked in Q4 of last year. So if you adjust for that, it looks like there is a slight increase. I'm just trying to understand the limits of what's under that guidance? And then secondly, just more generally, for this year, is your target to increase the dividend per share? And -- or anything you can comment on already on dividends?

FRéDéRIC OUDéA: I will let Philippe answer your first question. I think it's very premature, first of all, to comment on the dividend. But I must say we have announced a policy, which is to have a payout ratio of 50%, a floor at 2020, and we are not changing this policy, and we have applied this policy as early as 2017, and there's no change to be expected. Philippe, on the first question?

PHILIPPE HEIM: Yes. So on your question regarding this again. Yes, the whole story of the French Retail is to accelerate the transformation to deliver in 2020 event that is more efficient and with return on equity, we described today around 14%. So bottom line, we have to invest in the meantime. And yes, we took a specific provision in Q4 that -- let's be clear. From a net operating standpoint provision, it's there to, let's say, to cover cost or to cover investments that are not producing any cash flow in the future. So you can provision by on HR voluntary services some specific trending of mobility cost. But everything around let's say adopting the network coverage, everything around working on the processes is in the cost base. So we are, let's say, this year and in 2019, we will specifically mitigate budget for that, and we will see that in the cost base. But ultimately, between 2016 and 2020, this is consistent with the project (inaudible) because those 2 points, 2016, 2020 because they contain cumulative increase below 1%. And we'll deliver in 2020 headline savings of EUR 260 million. The point is that, we, as the effect, the benefit of reducing the footprint of branches, the benefit of reducing the number of people will be seen progressively. This is an ongoing process.

OPERATOR: Next question from Azzura Guelfi from Citigroup.

AZZURRA GUELFI, VP, CITIGROUP INC, RESEARCH DIVISION: Two questions for me. One on the leverage ratio and one on litigation. I'll start with litigation first. The second one is on leverage ratio. The leverage ratio still stand at the end of the peer group in terms of level, and this quarter has been going backwards a little bit. Could you explain to us what has been the main impact, I don't know, liquidity effects? And what could be the impact of this on your business? Is there any constraint on this level of leverage ratio?

FRéDéRIC OUDéA: I will let Philippe comment on the leverage ratio but there's no specific (inaudible)

results fundamentally like I would say probably all bank. Regarding litigation, well, I've commented already on LIA and LIBOR. On the OFAC, we stay with the idea, yes, we should in the coming weeks and months. So we pursue active discussions, but as it was the case 3, 4 months ago, there will be probably a slight time gap between the 3, but we remain optimistic to be able to put that behind us again in the coming weeks or months. And again what I want just to say, we did not change our global provisioning in the first quarter. We tried every time to assess whether we can do it and we did not change the level of provision. On the leverage ratio, Philippe?

PHILIPPE HEIM: Yes, so on leverage ratio, with the benefit of the additions we made in the beginning of April, we have leverage ratio of 4.2. I think that we are completely in line with our European deals. And then on top of that, as you know, there is a wide security debate on how you regulate banks in Europe. So focus not so much on leverage ratio. You have an American approach where what you're seeing is precisely organized on focusing the supervision on the leverage ratio and on (inaudible) in Europe. We are more on the side of the risk-based approach to risk-weighted assets and (inaudible). And if you analyze the leverage ratio of our peer group, we are completely in line with this peer group. Please bear in mind that the pressure applied by the regulation, by the Basel framework join this 3%, and we are moving towards something adding to the 3%, else the logistics of charge. So ultimately, the threshold that will be applicable to Societe Generalewill be 3.5%, and we want to maintain the bank, our leverage ratio between 4% and 4.5%.

OPERATOR: Next question from Jacques-Henri Gaulard from Kepler Cheuvreux.

JACQUES-HENRI MICHEL GAULARD, HEAD OF BANKS SECTOR RESEARCH, KEPLER CHEUVREUX, RESEARCH DIVISION: I have 2 questions on your management changes. First, Didier resigned basically on the 14th of March. And I was wondering if vis-Ã -vis, the investment banking business, this had any impact on the level of business that you've seen, I mean, over the following 6 weeks? And then I would like you to effectively give us a little bit more color on the process that led to the appointments of the management team. Obviously, do you choose to make appointments that were exclusively internal. I was wondering if there was a deliberate choice not to hire externally? Or if you had problems hiring externally?

FRéDéRIC OUDéA: Jacques-Henri, I don't think there had been a specific impact. Of course, such a departure, total departure is always difficult for the staff, the colleagues, but I would not, shall I say, it has had any significant impact. What is clear is that we wanted in the process to bring an answer relatively quickly and not to leave uncertainty for too long, and that's why we had this process. Regarding internal (inaudible), let me say our general policy, and I must say, it seems to me, it's the case for most companies, is at the deputy COO, CEO level, to try to bring people from internally. We pursue, of course, active policy to recruit whether it's a 25, 30, 35, 40. And if I may just state 2 of the appointments made -- announced yesterday. Typically, when I look at Philippe Helm or William Kadouch, both of them were not in the bank 10 years ago. They have very different profile initially. They joined the bank. We built a carrier just to check their capacity to integrate and develop. And we have now 2 managers [we're 50] and I think it's a better policy than trying to, by essence, recruit at such level. I must say, my experience, when you recruit, you have a 50% chance to make a mistake. And because how do you really know how people integrate their real capacity to share in vision, the values, et cetera, the behaviors of a team. So it's, I think, a policy which makes (inaudible) a lot of sense.

OPERATOR: Next question from Jean-Francois Neuez from Goldman Sachs.

JEAN-FRANCOIS NEUEZ, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP INC., RESEARCH DIVISION: This is Jean-Francois from Goldman. FRANK BENZIMRA: I think what we say last year, it was that floor activities were impacted by the low volatility environment. But it's mostly on the full activity that we are going to make (inaudible) the volatilities (inaudible).

BERNARDO SANCHEZ - INCERA, FORMER DEPUTY CEO, SOCIéTé GéNéRALE SOCIéTé ANONYME: So our current program is -- and we are talking specifically here about the French Retail activities. ALEX KOAGNE, HEAD OF BANKS SECTOR RESEARCH & ANALYST, NATIXIS S.A., RESEARCH DIVISION: Alex Koagne from Natixis, 2 questions from myself as well. The first question is for Frédéric. PHILIPPE HEIM: Yes. So Alex, so a few elements on the Corporate Centre. So we have indicated that we have a positive GOI this quarter on the Corporate Centre. And it can be explained by value [sentiment]. You have -- as [pretty secondly], you have the sensitivity effect due to a nonqualifying hedges. So you have the usual effects, and we try to park those effects in the Corporate Centre. They are volatile by nature. Is there any reason why we should not assume that your 2020 cost base will be lower than in 2018?

FRéDéRIC OUDéA: Stefan, first of all, totally unrelated, and we will announce his successor in the coming days, first question. STEFAN M. STALMANN: I think that from my perspective is that the 2020 guidance of your 1% CAGR gives me a higher cost number in 2020 than the now increased cost number for '18. So it looks your guidance implies that cost will continue to grow from '18 rather than come down.

OPERATOR: Next question from Omar Fall from Mediobanca.

OMAR FALL: Sorry to come back to equities, please, and apologies if I missed this somewhere, but you quote in the press release that prime services was at a record level in the quarter, which implies that the underlying performance in equities was materially worse than the minus 5% you've reported, given you've just had a restatement, which means we can't really confirm that. FRéDéRIC OUDéA: Omar, first question, auto calls, yes, we said we have limited growth for auto calls, and there was no change beginning of this quarter in terms of the nature of the structured product to be sold.
