urn:contentItem:4D01-C3F0-01GN-639K-00000-00Q2 2004 Dow Jones & Company Inc. Earnings Conference Call - Final2004-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:33ZLexisNexisTranscript 071504as.747Q2 2004 Dow Jones & Company Inc. Earnings Conference Call - Final

OPERATOR: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Dow Jones & Company second-quarter 2004 earnings conference call. At this time all participants are in a listen-only mode and a brief question-and-answer session will follow the formal presentation. [Caller Instructions] As reminder this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Mark Donohue, Director of Investor Relations for Dow Jones & Company. Thank you, Mr. Donohue, you may begin.

MARK DONOHUE, DIRECTOR, IR, DOW JONES & COMPANY INC.: Thank you. Good morning, welcome to our second-quarter 2004 earnings conference call and webcast at www.dowjones.com. On our call today are Peter Kann, Dow Jones Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Rich Zannino, our Chief Operating Officer; Chris Vieth, our Chief Financial Officer; Gordon Crovitz, Senior Vice President of Dow Jones and President of Electronic Publishing; and Karen House, Senior Vice President of Dow Jones and publisher of the "The Wall Street Journal". For your benefit, a transcript of today's prepared remarks will be on our website shortly after the conclusion of this call. Also, this teleconference call will be available by replay starting at 12 p.m. Eastern time today and ending at 5 p.m. on July 22. To access audio replay, please call 877-660-6853 enter account code 1628 and confirmation number 108661. Finally, should you have any questions after the call, please feel free to telephone Investor Relations at 609-520-5660.

As we begin our call, let me remind you that we will make certain forward-looking statements in an effort to assist you in understanding the Company's and its results. Actual results may materially differ from those presented here. Additional information concerning risk factors that could cause such a difference can be found in company's documents filed with the SEC from time to time. Reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures disclosed during this call are available in our earnings release which is available on the Investor Relations page of our website at www.dowjones.com. With that, it's a pleasure to turn our call over to Peter Kann.

PETER KANN, CHAIRMAN & CEO, DOW JONES & COMPANY INC.: Good morning, and thank you all for joining us. On this morning's call, I'm going to touch very briefly on some highlights of the quarter. Chris Vieth, our CFO, will take you through the financial results, and then Rich Zannino, our Chief Operating Officer, is going to elaborate with operating highlights and third-quarter outlook; and then we'll try to take any questions you may have. We, once again, are pleased to be reporting earnings per share growth, as well as lineage gains for the fourth quarter in a row. Excluding special items, we earned 41 cents per diluted share, which is up 52% from 27 cents per diluted share in the second quarter last year. We're pleased with the improved revenue and bottom-line results at all three of our business segments, and at virtually all of our products and services. And our strong operating leverage was evident once again as an 11% increase in revenue resulted in a 62% increase in operating income.

On the Electronic Publishing side, we had another strong quarter of revenue growth at Dow Jones Indexes and at Consumer Electronic Publishing. Within our Newswires businesses, we successfully integrated our recent acquisitions of Alternative Investor Group and VWD. And our community newspaper group, Ottaway continues to post strong revenue growth and profit, while maintaining one of the highest margins among its peers; and Chris and Rich are going to review those results with you in more detail very shortly. At our Print Publishing segment where revenue and profits also were up, color advertising continues to grow, up 22% in the second quarter and up 32% for the first half of 2004; and that follows strong color ad growth of 28% in 2003 and 34% in 2002. Companies continue to pay premium rates to take advantage of our high-quality color advertising to reach our attractive and unique global audience. We've also continued to attract new advertisers such as Nautica, Nordstrom, Quester, Wyndham Hotels and more.

Our popular Personal Journal section is benefiting as more and more advertisers are realizing that our readers have a strong propensity to spend on high-end consumer goods. Personal Journal ad lineage is up more than 52% in 2004 and actually is approaching the healthy ad levels in our very successful weekend Journal section. While we are seeing encouraging trends in a number of our businesses, we continue to caution that the business-to-business ad environment remains somewhat volatile. Our recent lineage trends reflect this, as we saw per issue lineage at the Journal in April and May up around 7% while June was down 3.5%; which adds up to the 3.3% increase for the quarter. This month-to-month ad volatility has been a reality for about a year now. This, in turn, has been driven by inconsistent trends across major ad categories which we see continuing into the third quarter, and even as we post some positive gains, we're well aware that ad levels remain significantly below what we consider normal preboom, prebust levels.

In the meantime, we continue to focus on product quality, on effective sales efforts and sensible investments, and operating efficiencies and cost controls; all as set out in our strategic plan, Business Now. During the quarter, we once again were recognized for the quality of our products as the "Wall Street Journal" was honored with a number of globe awards and Newswires won its second straight annual news provider of the year award from Inside Market Data. We also won several Cody awards as Dow Jones News Plus, a Business Now initiative won its first ever Cody and the Online Journal brought home two more. We are also pleased to announce that a few weeks ago we did reach a settlement with IAPE, that is the union that represents about 25% of our employees; which includes many of the "The Wall Street Journal" newspeople. This agreement has the support and endorsement of -- and endorsement of the union's bargaining committee, its executive council, and Board of Directors. It is going to go to the IAPE membership for ratification shortly -- excuse me -- [ coughing ] -- sorry--for ratification shortly.

The agreement -- the tentative agreement represents a full and-- [ coughing ] -- excuse me, a full and fair resolution of many difficult issues and that should enable all of us to devote our full attention going forward to our publications, our products and, of course, our customers. With that, I am going to hand it over to Chris for a review of financial results.

CHRIS VIETH, VP & CFO, DOW JONES & COMPANY INC.: Thank you, Peter and good morning, everyone. This morning I'll briefly cover the key business drivers behind our second-quarter financial results which we reported earlier today. Before special items, second quarter earnings per share were 41 cents this year, which is above the current First Call mean of 38 cents and 52% above last year's earnings of 27 cents per share. Year-to-date through June, total revenue is up 12% and EPS, before special items, were 63 cents per share and 62% above the same period of 2003 as we continue to significantly leverage our cost reductions. Total company revenue was in line with our expectations of an 11% increase for the quarter, with increased revenues at Electronic Publishing and Ottaway offsetting slightly lower-than-expected advertising revenue at Print Publishing. Lower operating expenses across the portfolio drove the improved earnings performance versus our April guidance. Second-quarter revenue increased to $438 million, including roughly 3.5% of the increase from our recent acquisitions, Stockton Technologic Partner, Alternative Investors and VWD.

Please note that this is the last quarter we will report Stockton results to you separately as an acquisition as we have now anniversaried our May 2003 purchase of the property. Second-quarter operating expenses of $382 million were up roughly 6% over last year, before special items, and better than our April guidance of an 8% increase as we continue to tightly control expenses at all business units. This included approximately 3% related to our recent acquisitions, less than 1% for increased newsprint expenses and 1% associated with the increased foreign currency costs. All other expenses were up only 2% over last year, including a $2 million charge for a small workforce reduction in circulation distribution at the Journal, part of our Business Now priority to improve circulation efficiency. Nearly offsetting this charge was a nontaxable benefit of, roughly, $1.5 million related to accounting for the Medicare Prescription Drug Act. We will save a similar amount in the second half of 2004 as a result of that change. Our second-quarter ending head count totalled about 7,150 and, excluding employees associated with our acquisitions, comparable head count was down 2% from last year's second quarter.

Looking at some other key figures. Total newsprint costs in the quarter were up a little more than 5% with consumption down 2% and our average cost per ton up about 8% versus year-ago levels. We are staying at roughly $30 per ton on the February price increase took hold by the time it was all said and done. And as we have done in the past, we also used inventory where possible to mitigate some of the impact. Our internal forecasts also anticipate a late-summer price increase that follows the path of last year's. That is it takes a few months to stick, and when it does, not at the full announced rate. Before special items, our effective tax rate was 40.9% for the quarter and is expected to come in around 41% for the year. Capital expenditures totalled $15 million in the second quarter compared with $12 million last year. We continue to tightly manage working capital and cash flow items and our cash flow and balance sheet remain strong.

After capital expenditures, dividends, investments, and all other outflows, we used $33 million of excess cash flow plus $11 million of cash to reduce our debt by another $44 million in the quarter. We closed the second-quarter 2004 with debt of $215 million, versus a debt level of $210 million in last year's second quarter and $258 million at the end of the first-quarter 2004. With a seasonally low third quarter for ad volume at the Journal, we expect our excess cash flow to be about flat in the third quarter returning sharply positive in the fourth quarter which we'll use to reduce our debt balance further. With that, I'll turn it over to Rich.

RICH ZANNINO, EVP & COO, DOW JONES & COMPANY INC.: Thanks, Chris. Good morning all, and thanks for joining us. In the second quarter, we posted significant gains in revenue, earnings, and margins in each of our three business segments. This marks the fourth consecutive quarter of such gains. We've also posted increased advertising lineage at "The Wall Street Journal" for the past four consecutive quarters. As a result, revenue is up 9%, operating income is up 53%, and EPS before special items is up 52% over these past four quarters. So we're definitely seeing a payback on our Business Now initiatives, as well as a modest recovery in the B-to-B advertising environment; however, pleased as we are with this progress, it's not enough. Our Print Publishing ad volumes and, thus, our overall earnings are being constrained by the cyclically soft B-to-B ad environment and are well below what we consider normal levels. Peter noted we haven't yet gotten all cylinders firing together. And, while we can't entirely control this, we must continue to control everything else that we can as we did in the second quarter.

But before getting into these second quarter results, I would like review the terms of our tentative new labor contract IAPE, the union that represents about 1,600 of our employees; including those in news, advertising sales, technology, circulation, and administrative areas. These folks have been working without a contract since April of 2003. And after much negotiation, we've agreed to pay them wage increases of 0% in 2003, 2.5% in 2004, 3.25% in 2005, and 3.5% in 2006. Also, we will make lump sum payments totaling $2,000 to each IAPE employee. In addition, IAPE members will be subject to the company's new medical plan effective on January 1, 2005. This new plan, which other DJ employees enrolled in effective January 1, 2004, incorporates design changes aimed at reducing costs for both employees and the Company; and, for the first time, requires employees to contribute to monthly medical premiums. We believe the settlement is fair to both IAPE members and DJ shareholders. Taken together, the lump sum payments and wages increases are in line with those settled at other publishers. The new medical plan, while still very generous by competitive standards, will help slow the rapid escalation in company medical costs.

Taken together, these items enable us to continue to control costs in this still uncertain revenue environment. We'll incur one-time costs of about $4 million in the third quarter and $2 million in the fourth-quarter 2004 for the lump sum payments. After adding in an additional $1,000 payment for each non-IAPE, non-management employee to keep them whole with IAPE members. With all IAPE and non-IAPE employees now subject to the new medical plan, we expect to save nearly $9 million annually in medical and retiree health costs. And finally, the agreement is subject to a ratification vote by the IAPE membership, and we would hope to have the whole process wrapped up in the next six weeks or so. We look forward to putting this difficult episode behind us so we may refocus 100% of all of our attentions on running the business and getting back to creating, selling, and supporting great products.

And now on to our segment results. Our Print Publishing total revenue was up 8% from a year ago. Operating income more than tripled to $17 million and margins grew to 6.8%. We said that, in an improving ad environment, about 80 cents of every new dollar of Journal advertising revenue flows through to the bottom line. This flow-through was 60% in the second quarter, but adjusting for increased newsprint prices and foreign currency costs, this flow-through was 78%; very close to our 80% target. Making similar adjustments for the full year, we expect to hit our 80% target for the full year. We saw continued volatility in monthly comps at the U.S. Journal, with per issue lineage in April and May each up around 7%; in June, down 3.5%. This led to an increase of 3.3% in ad lineage at the U.S. Journal for the quarter. While we'd obviously prefer to see a more consistent trend and faster pace in lineage levels we're, nonetheless, very pleased that the Journal is outpacing its competitors and increasing its market share in this difficult B-to-B advertising environment.

As we've said in the past, and as all of you know, our fortunes can't significantly improve without a sustained turnaround in the Journal's two biggest engines, financial and technology advertising. While financial advertising has been relatively strong through the first half of 2004, unfortunately, technology advertising has been weak. Financial advertising increased 5.3% in the second quarter as strong wholesale advertising more than offset weakness in tombstone and retail financial advertising. This was the third consecutive quarter of increases in financial advertising volume and we're cautiously optimistic it will strengthen a bit in the second half, with continued strength in wholesale and improved trends in tombstone and retail ads. On the other hand technology lineage was down 28% in the quarter. During the second half of 2004, particularly in the third quarter of 2004, we're expecting technology ad spending to remain weak due to a combination of tough comps in last year's second half and cutbacks in ad budgets at many large B-to-B tech companies driven by their spotty profit growth and uncertain outlook for global technology spending.

In the Journal's general advertising category, lineage was up 15% in the second quarter on strong increases in professional services, insurance, luxury, travel, and healthcare advertising categories. Auto was down a modest 4% in the quarter; however, we expect the auto category to rebound in the second half of the year as comps ease and we see a number of new vehicles and incentive programs launch in the fall. And finally, the Journal posted an 11% increase in classified and other lineage in the quarter, driven by strong increases in real estate, recruitment and other classified advertising. Looking beyond lineage to ad revenue, we're very pleased that for the fourth consecutive quarter, ad revenue gains at the Journal significantly outpaced lineage gains. In the second quarter, we post posted a 9.5% increase in advertising revenue at the Journal on a 3.3% increase in ad lineage.

Today's Journal continues to drive positive results. The expanded color capacity in Today's Journal drove a 22% increase in color ad pages and 32% increase in color ad revenue during the quarter. We're averaging roughly 8 full color page equivalents per day out of our total color advertising capacity of up to 20 pages per day. Color pages have nearly doubled since we increased color capacity at the end of 2001. We're also using Today's Journal in our new Personal Journal section to expand consumer advertising to reduce our reliance on financial and tech advertising. Our targeted consumer categories of auto, travel, healthcare and luxury consumer goods showed lineage gains of 8% and revenue gains of 13% during the second quarter. Ad revenue in these categories is up about 24% since the end of 2001. Elsewhere in Print Publishing, at the Asian and European editions of the Journal, total advertising lineage increased 6% per issue in the quarter on strength in nearly all categories; offset by weakness in tech advertising.

And at Barron's, ad pages increased a healthy 21% in the quarter driven by very strong financial and auto advertising. Moving on now to Electronic Publishing, we continue to improve our products, profits, and industry-leading margins. Second-quarter revenue was up 20%, operating income was up 43%, and operating margins were up 370 basis points to 23.8% over the same period last year. Excluding acquisitions, revenue was up 7%, operating income was up 29%, and margins were up 430 basis points driven by strong revenue and profit performance at both Consumer Electronic Publishing and Dow Jones Indexes. At Newswires, revenue was up 21% driven by the recent acquisitions of Tech Partners, Alternative Investors, and VWD. The integration of these acquisitions is going as planned and we're on track to meet our profit projections. Revenue in Newswires core business was about flat during the second quarter.

At Consumer Electronic Publishing, second quarter revenue was up 13%, driven by a 35% increase in online advertising revenue and 4.5% increase in circulation revenue. Subscribers at the end of the second quarter was 684,000, up 2% over the second-quarter 2003, and down slightly from the first-quarter of 2004. Importantly, usage of our paid site, WSJ.com, as measured by unique visitors was up 13% during the quarter. As you may have noticed in our earnings release, we have changed our methodology for counting aggregate unique visitors to and page views at our free and paid websites. This change takes advantage of new technology to more accurately measure site usage which will help us sell more ads and improve user experience at these sites. It's more conservative, in as much as, it lowers the number of page views and unique visitors. Unfortunately, it renders year-over-year comparisons invalid as we are unable to restate prior periods. Nonetheless, we believe we continued to increase usage of our websites during the second quarter and will continue to do so going forward.

At Ottaway, second-quarter revenue was up 11%, operating income was up 17%, and operating margins were up 160 basis points to 28.7% over last year. Revenue gains were driven by the May 2003 acquisition of the Stockton Record and same property revenue growth of 6.4% which, in turn, was driven by a 5.5% increase in ad lineage in the quarter with strong auto and real estate classified lineage. Same property operating income at Ottaway was up 13% over last year's second quarter. Looking forward, ad buyers continue to make buying decisions very close to publication dates, making visibility and projections difficult. Having said this, for the third quarter, recent trends appear likely to continue. That is, we don't yet see all our main cylinders firing together. More specifically, while we expect continued gains in financial wholesale, general B-to-B, consumer and classified advertising, and expect improved trends in auto, tombstone, and financial retail advertising; much of this is likely to be offset by weakness in technology advertising, as well as in travel advertising, as we're up against very difficult post-war comps in travel ads.

By month, we expect per issue lineage comps at the Journal to be down slightly in the slow summer months of July and August, followed by a nice gain in the busier month of September, all leading to third-quarter lineage of up in the low single-digit range. Together with continued strong gains elsewhere in the portfolio this level of lineage gain would result in an 8% increase in total revenue for the third quarter. On the expense line, we'll continue to hold on to the vast majority of our cost reductions. We expect total operating expenses to be up about 6% in the third quarter. Of this, about 4% is due to expenses for our recent acquisitions, increased newsprint and foreign currency costs, and the lump sum payment related to our tentative labor contract settlement. This leaves comparable expenses up only 2% over last year. The net of all this is an EPS estimate, before special items, of about 20 cents per share for the third quarter; and this is after deducting about 3 cents per share for the lump sum payment related to our tentative labor contract. This is up from 14 cents per share last year.

In closing, in the second quarter, we improved revenue, profit and margins virtually everywhere in our portfolio. At Electronic Publishing and Ottaway, we increased our margins, which were already near the top of their peer groups, and at Print Publishing we got another strong glimpse of how highly leveraged our earnings growth is to an improving ad environment. Going forward, we'll continue to control everything we can to maximize our upside as the ad environment continues to improve. And with that we'll turn it back to the operator to open the phone lines for questions.

OPERATOR: Certainly. Ladies and gentlemen, at this time, we will be conducting the question-and-answer section. [Caller Instructions] Thank you. Our first question for the day will come from Peter Appert of Goldman Sachs.

PETER APPERT, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Rich, apologies if you covered this in the comments, but I might have missed it. What is the organic revenue and operating income growth for the Electronic Publishing segment in the second quarter?

RICH ZANNINO: Peter, we did cover it, and if you exclude acquisitions, revenue was up 7%, operating income was up 29%, and margins were up 430 basis points to 24.4%.

PETER APPERT: Right. And the primary driver of the margin gain is just the inherent operating leverage in the business model?

RICH ZANNINO: Absolutely.

PETER APPERT: Okay. Anything specific in terms of price adjustments or particular units within Electronic Publishing that is driving that margin gain?

RICH ZANNINO: Go ahead, Gordon.

GORDON CROVITZ, SVP, DOW JONES, & PRESIDENT, ELECTRONIC PUBLISHING, DOW JONES & COMPANY INC.: Hi Peter, this is Gordon Crovitz. I think -- I encourage you to take a look at the leverage now that we're seeing in our online operations where the advertising increase of some 35% has continued pretty nicely. Our Dow Jones Indexes business also had very significant revenue increases and that's become a very significant margin business.

PETER APPERT: And how about -- what do you think a normalized level of margin for the Electronic Publishing business might be over the next couple of years?

GORDON CROVITZ: I think, as Rich said, we're already toward the very top of our peer group so I wouldn't want to suggest that it can go a lot higher than now. We're very focused on growing the top line while maintaining these kinds of margins.

PETER APPERT: Okay. And then last question. Rich, the Print Publishing business has been unprofitable for the last several years in the third quarter. Is the revenue momentum you're seeing currently sufficient to get you to profitability in the third quarter this year?

RICH ZANNINO: We are going to look at that, Peter. If you want to take another question, and I will come back to that one.

OPERATOR: Certainly. Our next question will come from Doug Arthur of Morgan Stanley.

DOUG ARTHUR, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: Rich, specifically on tombstone advertising, why is it not better and is -- is there somewhat of a secular change here where in a more regulatory scrutinized environment, investment banks are hesitant to take out big ads announcing deals, or is this a function of deal size?

RICH ZANNINO: That's a good question, and maybe it will help to put it in some context. First of all, pure tombstones and new issue advertising represents about 5% to 6% of total "Wall Street Journal" lineage depending on the year. So while it's a meaningful category, it's nowhere near as large and as meaningful as some of the other financial categories or as some of the tech categories or even auto. To put it in perspective, it's about the same size as our travel and professional services advertising categories. So that -- that gives you some dimension on our exposure to tombstone advertising.

Having said that, tombstone advertising, we believe, is a function of four factors: Deal flow, and we all see that getting much stronger. Deal size, and while deals are getting bigger, most of them are still pretty small. Deal performance would be a third -- would be a third factor, and deal performance has been a bit sketchy here so far this year. I think 34 out of 100 deals that have gone off this year are underperforming their offer price, their IPO price. And then finally, there has been a moratorium, if you will, on the part of some of the major investment banks against running tombstone ads. So we think those are the four factors that are driving -- that drive tombstone advertising that are driving it in the current environment.

I have not heard anything so far, Doug, about the regulatory environment constraining banks in running tombstones. I think some of the larger banks have basically questioned the value of a tombstone ad, and we have lots of research that we share with them, and more and more now with the issuers on the value of tombstone ads and the value is significant. People look at them, they act on them. They call the banks. And they are a call to action for people to do things with the banks. So we think research supports the value of a tombstone ad.

To put some numbers -- other numbers against all of that, so far this year, there have been 100 IPOs priced. We've received tombstones on 22 of those so far. About 40 from the so-called moratorium banks, and the remaining 38, we'll get some of those, but many of them are too small and are underperforming. Again, 34 out of the 100 are underperforming so we won't get those. You know, the good news, if you will, is we see the calendar strengthening in the balance of the year. We see the banks that are doing the deals. We think we're going to see increased momentum in the back half of the year and get back into positive territory again like we were in the first quarter on tombstone advertising. Of course, nobody else is getting these tombstones; they're not going anywhere else. Journal still has 100% market share for tombstone.

And so I think there is another 200 or so deals in the pipeline for the balance of the year, and, you know, we'll get -- we'll get our share of those. But I think summing that all up, it's a relatively small category. It's not all going away. We are working hard to get as many tombstones as we can by going directly to issuers with our research and to the banks with our research; and, given the pipeline going forward, and the pipeline does have a few very large deals, not the least of which is Google going forward. So going forward, we think we will see, you know, positive comps again in the category.

CHRIS VIETH: Answering Peter Appert. This is Chris -- Peter Appert's earlier call, Print Publishing operating income was negative $11.5 million last year. We'll make significant progress against that this year and reduce it, but it will still be negative in the third quarter.

RICH ZANNINO: And, of course, the U.S. Journal will be profitable in the third quarter this year as it was in the third quarter last year.

OPERATOR: Our next question will come from Christa Sober from Thomas Weisel Partners.

CHRISTA SOBER, ANALYST, THOMAS WEISEL PARTNERS: Hi. Couple questions. First, could you remind us what color is as a percentage of total Journal. Second, you talked about low single-digit lineage in the third quarter. Obviously, we saw low single in the second quarter. Can we expect, I guess, a similar yield off of that lineage in the third quarter as we saw in the second quarter? And then finally, Gordon, could you tell us what tech spending was up online? We saw pretty strong growth from CNET yesterday and I'm just wondering if the online trends are mirroring the offline in tech spending. Thanks.

RICH ZANNINO: Christa, color represents about 30% of our total lineage, and it would be a higher percentage of our total revenue because color, a full-page sells at 27% premium to black and white and a half page sells at 37% premium to black and white. But we always talk lineage, so the -- it's about 30% of total Journal lineage. As far as yield, we hope to be able to -- to continue to have revenue growth in excess of lineage growth in advertising. And would hope to see -- it might not be 6% in the third quarter in terms of the spread between lineage growth and revenue growth, but we would hope it would be in the 4% to 5% range. It will depend somewhat on mix ultimately, you know the mix between classified and -- and display advertising. But color should drive it, and our new rate card should drive it, and favorable mix in some of our other categories should definitely continue to help it.

CHRIS VIETH: Christa, in terms of online advertising. As you mentioned the advertising in total increased 35%. Display advertising up 37%. Technology and financial, those two categories really dominate the online categories. And you asked particularly about technology spending. That was in line with the overall percentage increase that we saw this quarter.

CHRISTA SOBER: Great, thank you so much.

OPERATOR: Thank you. Our next question will come from Paul Ginocchio of Deutsche Bank.

PAUL GINOCCHIO, ANALYST, DEUTSCHE BANK: Sorry. Hi there. Could you give us how the yield looked in Q3, the mix of it between price and color and the components? And then also, the deceleration that happened in consumer electronic publishing in Q2 versus Q1. Where that came from? Thanks.

RICH ZANNINO: Paul, we had a little trouble hearing the first part of your question. Could you repeat that?

PAUL GINOCCHIO: Sure. Just wanted to get the mix of the yield -- 6% yield improvement in Q2. Can you break down that and its components?

RICH ZANNINO: Between how much was driven by color versus how much was driven by rate --

PAUL GINOCCHIO: rate increase and then just, I guess, mix.

RICH ZANNINO: Yeah, I think--

PAUL GINOCCHIO: And relative to Q1 where it was 10.

RICH ZANNINO: Yeah, well in Q1, it was certainly driven more by mix, because in Q1, display advertising, I think, was actually very close to classified advertising, and in the -- and in Q2, our display advertising was up low single-digits, and our classified advertising was up 11%. So classified runs at a much lower ad rate, line rate than display. So that would explain the difference between Q1 and Q2. Just -- the heavier proportion of the mix of classified in Q2.

PAUL GINOCCHIO: Perfect. Thanks. Then the -- the deceleration of CEP, what was the driver of that from Q1 --

RICH ZANNINO: Are you talking about subs there?

PAUL GINOCCHIO: No, the 13% year-on-year revenue growth in CEP in Q1--or Q2 versus the 18 in Q1.

PETER KANN: Gordon?

GORDON CROVITZ: Part of that, Paul, is the fact that the subscriber is paying the full new price increase over time obviously, a higher and higher percentage of them are doing that. Two-thirds of the revenue for the Online Journal is from subscriptions and so even as we see very large increases in advertising revenue, the subscription revenue tends to move more in line with volume.

PAUL GINOCCHIO: Rich, refresh my memory what the advertising for CEP was in Q1.

RICH ZANNINO: It was in line with this quarter. In the mid-30s.

PAUL GINOCCHIO: Great, thank you.

OPERATOR: Our next question will come from Lauren Fine of Merrill Lynch.

LAUREN FINE, ANALYST, MERRILL LYNCH: Thank you. I -- could we just go over the technology outlook for the second half again? I guess I'm surprised. I was under the impression that it was going to improve and I'm wondering if something has changed from earlier calls; and it sounds like maybe you are basing it, again, on some of the profit reports that had come out which would make sense. And then also, could you just give us a sense of what you were paying in newsprint per ton in the quarter and the timing of when you might have paid an increase in the quarter and what you expect to happen in the second half?

PETER KANN: Chris can take the newsprint I think.

CHRIS VIETH: Yeah, just Lauren, the newsprint price increase that was announced on February 1, it came in slowly. Some suppliers raised, you know put through the price increase on invoices right away. Others didn't. We also used inventory to buy around some of the price increases. So by the time it was all said and done at the end of the second quarter, we were up about $30 a ton. Traditionally, we have steered away from actually quoting the price per ton that we pay, but what we have said is that, you know, for the year, we expect newsprint expenses to be up about 11% over last year; and we expect, you know, newsprint price increase in the late summer to follow the trends of what they did last year, and all of that has remained constant with our guidance from the beginning of the year. So we are pretty much consistent with what our expectations are there.

LAUREN FINE: Okay.

RICH ZANNINO: Lauren, on your tech question. I would just like to clarify the way you started it. We actually said in the first quarter that we expected tech to be soft for the balance of the year. You might be confusing us with another large daily newspaper -- [ LAUGHTER ]

LAUREN FINE: That's possible.

RICH ZANNINO: Projecting it to be up in the back half of the year. But we -- our tech category includes tech and telecom in that category. We're up against pretty tough comps in the back half of last year. We were up about 13% in the back half last year. So we're up against that. We are also seeing some of the big tech guys cut back on their budgets. I mean you read in the last week or so, Microsoft saying they want to cut $1 billion in expense, and to do it without cutting head count. You know -- and my guess is they're not going to cut R&D either. So I think we're up against tough comps.

People are cutting their budgets because they're not seeing the profit growth that they want to see. They are also a little bit skittish given what people have been saying lately about future plans for -- lately about future plans for capital spending on technology products. So I think they're being cautious. Having said that, we think the third quarter will be a much tougher quarter than the fourth quarter. We think we'll see an improvement in trend during the fourth quarter just based on -- on some of the RFPs that are out there and some indications we are getting from some of the big tech spenders in terms of their plans for the fourth quarter. So while we're saying the back half will be weak, it's -- we -- we're predicting it to be much weaker in the third quarter and then to come back somewhat in the fourth quarter.

LAUREN FINE: Okay. And just one last question. In terms of global ad sales across the properties. Can you give us an update on how that's going?

KAREN HOUSE, SVP, DOW JONES & PUBLISHER, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL, DOW JONES & COMPANY INC.: Lauren, this is -- excuse me, Karen House. Our global advertising revenue continues to grow.

LAUREN FINE: Would you say it is meeting your expectations?

KAREN HOUSE: It has actually exceeded budget this year. So it is exceeding our expectations.

LAUREN FINE: Great. Thank you.

RICH ZANNINO: We actually saw a nice -- a nice improvement in ad yield in our International publications as well as this year driven in large part by the global rate program and the rate increase we put in this year to the global rate programs.

KAREN HOUSE: And we're growing in share in both Europe and Asia, which is obviously pleasing.

LAUREN FINE: Could you actually refresh our memory on what you raised rates on the global rate and on the U.S. Journal?

KAREN HOUSE: We raised the rate for the overseas publication 25%. What it -- what I do remember --

RICH ZANNINO: which was probably --

KAREN HOUSE: rate increase --

RICH ZANNINO: the net effect of -- we put through roughly a 5% global rate increase, but we gave -- the entire 5% we're crediting to the international pubs as it should be because they took the discount when we originally put the global rate in. So it represents about a 25% increase in ad rates for the international publications in terms of their share of that new higher global rate. And then in the U.S., we put through on the rate card a 3% rate increase, but we also made some other changes to the rate card, which we hoped and, in fact, it has materialized, would drive it higher than 3% increase in yield.

LAUREN FINE: Great, thank you.

PETER KANN: We increased the price of color premium as well.

RICH ZANNINO: Yeah, the color premium went from 25 to 27 on a full page and from 35 to 37 on a half page.

LAUREN FINE: Wonderful. Thank you.

OPERATOR: Thank you. Our next question will come from Craig Super of Lehman Brothers.

CRAIG HUBER, ANALYST, LEHMAN BROTHERS: It's actually Craig Huber. Thank you. Two questions. Can you give us the annual run rate of your newsletter Business Now with the acquisitions? Second question, some of your other peers have really stepped up here recently to increase their share buybacks substantially. I was wondering what your plans are on that front given that your stock has pulled back? Thanks.

PETER KANN: Yeah, we'll let Chris take the share buyback question and then Gordon will follow on the first part.

CHRIS VIETH: Sure, Craig, with regard to share buyback. For at least the next few quarters, we'll continue to direct excess cash flow to reduce our commercial paper balance, which, as I said earlier, is now down to about $215 million. In the past, we've utilized share repurchase when conditions were right. That is, when we've had excess cash flow and debt capacity. When our shares are trading below their intrinsic value, when the return on investment in shares exceeds that of alternate uses of the capitol and when we've had board authorization to repurchase shares. All of these conditions exist today except for our debt and we're making good progress here down another $44 million in the third quarter. In the future, when all of these conditions are met, we could be back in the market again, but for now we are directing our cash to pay down our debt levels.

GORDON CROVITZ: And, Craig, on your question about newsletters. We've created a new division within Dow Jones Newswires, as a result of our acquisition of Alternate Investor and Tech Partners last year, called Financial Information Services that includes newsletters, databases and events. That'll have revenues. This year our analyzed revenues -- revenues this year in the mid-20s. I think -- might think about this more broadly which is about a third of all of revenues for Dow Jones Newswires this year will be from products or sales channels we didn't have a few years ago that are not dependent on traditional market data terminals; and this, of course, is another reason why there's a growing gap between the terminal count and revenue lines. We have the financial information services division, local language, wires around the world, local website revenues, many other sources, which is why we are no longer nearly so dependent on head count trends among our customers.

CRAIG HUBER: While I have you here, Gordon, Factiva had a very healthy pickup in operating income in the quarter. Do you expect that to continue here or it it a one off?

GORDON CROVITZ: Yeah, no we're very, very pleased with the performance of Factiva and its continued success in its market. Its operating income, as you saw, more than tripled to almost $9 million. Part of that was driven by a one-time cost reduction associated with the finalization of the migration this time last year to Factiva-related products, that is the sun setting of Dow Jones interactive and business briefing products. Revenue growth has been sharp and consistent every month since that migration ended. The sales team at Factiva's been able to focus on net new installations rather than upgrades, and we have had net new installations in positive territory every month since August, 2003. So I think you will continue to see performance improvement at Factiva. I don't think we'll necessarily see operating income increases in this range every quarter. But it's a very solid business, making very strong gains in its market.

CRAIG HUBER: Great, thank you.

OPERATOR: Thank you. Our next question will come from Steve Barlow of Prudential Equity Group.

STEVE BARLOW, ANALYST, PRUDENTIAL EQUITY GROUP: Thank you. Gordon, while we're on the topic and maybe it's related more to Chris, what would be the annual number for the equity line for 2004? Secondly, I believe you-- you've had a price increase on home delivery of the "The Wall Street Journal". I wanted to see how that is impacting your copies at this point. Thanks.

CHRIS VIETH: I think what -- what you mean is subscription price increase, right?

STEVE BARLOW: Yes. Yeah.

RICH ZANNINO: That went in April 1, Steve, so too early to tell in terms of getting a reaction. But retention rates are up. Conversion rates are up. And acquisition rates are up in circulation at the -- at the Journal. So -- but it's too early to tell, yet, the impact of -- of the -- I think it was $10 price increase that went into effect on April 1.

CHRIS VIETH: As far as -- Steve, as far equity investments for the year we haven't given guidance for the fourth quarter yet, but we expect it to be, you know, modestly better than last year at this point. It will be above last year.

STEVE BARLOW: And lastly, Chris, on the stock buyback question. Where do you want your leverage to go down to? Your leverage isn't all that high to start with, and you're sort of suggesting that condition has not been met yet.

CHRIS VIETH: Yeah, that's a good question. You know, our internal target, what we are shooting for right now as far as, think about it from a debt-level perspective, is about, you know,-- we'd like to get it down to 100 million. We've had it -- last year it was down to 93 million and in years' past it had averaged around $150 million. As you saw S&P dropped us a notch last quarter largely on the kind of volatility we've had in Print Publishing advertising revenues. So, you know, those credit metrics are important to us and we're going to continue to dedicate our cash flow to drive down that debt level for the near term, at least the next few quarters.

STEVE BARLOW: Thank you.

OPERATOR: Thank you. Our next question will come from James Easterland of Oak Value Capital.

JAMES EASTERLAND, ANALYST, OAK VALUE CAPITAL: Thanks, my question has been answered.

OPERATOR: Thank you. Our next question will come from William Drewry of Credit Suisse First Boston.

WILLIAM DREWRY, ANALYST, CREDIT SUISSE FIRST BOSTON: Hi, thanks. Couple of questions. One, Rich, I don't think you covered it. On the union issue. Just wondering if there's any other contracts over the near-term, near-to-immediate term with any other unions that are up for renewal? Second question. Just wondering, if you look out for the full year based on the current trend lines, how big WSJ.com will be, this year now, in terms of revenue and any margin contribution you can speak to? And then just on the tech advertising, just to try to put it in just a bit more perspective, wondering if you could give us what your -- what your best guess is at the dollar run rate right now? Where that was, maybe a year ago, and then where that was at the peak for the -- just for the tech category or the way you look at it, maybe tech and telecom. Thank you.

PETER KANN: Bill, on the first question, no this--the IAPE contract is the, far and away, the most significant labor contract, and there aren't any others like that sitting out there open. And Gordon?

GORDON CROVITZ: In terms of the online Journal, we have had strong double-digit revenue gains so far this year. We'd expect that to continue -- to continue for the full year as well. In terms of operating income, you know we don't break it down quite that way. But I would say, you know, several million dollars' worth of operating income from the online Journal, and a margin that, as you know, has turned positive, and we think has got potential margin that may be closer in its dynamics to a traditional publishing business then necessarily to advertising driven business inasmuch as the subscription revenues continue to be a significant part of its revenue base.

WILLIAM DREWRY: Gordon, could you just compare it either in -- in dollar amount or either percentage terms to the -- to the print Journal?

GORDON CROVITZ: What, the revenue or the margin?

WILLIAM DREWRY: Just revenue -- I'm sorry just revenue.

GORDON CROVITZ: The -- the question is the percentage of revenue for the online Journal versus the print?

WILLIAM DREWRY: Yeah, or just give us the dollar volume. How much do you think it will do this year? You know, $75 million, $100 million?

GORDON CROVITZ: I think rather than giving a precise number, I would say it is in the range of the lower amount you just asked about.

WILLIAM DREWRY: Perfect. Perfect. And tech -- tech dollars?

RICH ZANNINO: Yeah. If -- if technology is -- you know I -- the numbers -- the run rate of technology this year compared to where it was in 2000, which was just obviously an enormous boom year, our technology lineage is about a third of what it was in 2000. And, you know, and it is obviously below where it was and what we consider to be the normal -- the more normal year of '98. It's probably somewhere around half of what it was in 1998. Now, that's lineage. So the revenue will be a little --the spread between revenue in those years will be a little tighter, but, you know, that's the -- that's the lineage picture. We have got tremendous upside in technology lineage.

WILLIAM DREWRY: That would just be tighter because you put through price increases since the peak?

RICH ZANNINO: Exactly.

WILLIAM DREWRY: Perfect. Thanks very much.

RICH ZANNINO: Thank you.

OPERATOR: Ladies and gentlemen, there appear to be no further questions at this time. Gentlemen, would you like to make closing comments?

PETER KANN: We just want to thank everyone who spent the last hour with us today. Thank you.

OPERATOR: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for your participation in today's Dow Jones teleconference. You may all disconnect your lines at this time and have a wonderful day. Thank you.
